questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. His fasting triglyceride levels are 1100 mg/dL. He mentions that his mother was diagnosed with a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase, and on further investigation, he too was diagnosed with the same condition. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this patient's plasma?

VLDL- very-low-density lipoprotein

LDL- low-density lipoprotein

HDL- high-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of lipoprotein lipase deficiency indicate a diagnosis of type I hyperlipoproteinemia, where chylomicron and VLDL levels will be elevated.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency, is due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency, causing inactivation of LPL. It is an autosomal recessive condition. 

Genetic deficiency or inactivity of LPL results in impaired lipolysis and profound elevations in plasma triglycerides, mostly in chylomicrons. These patients often have elevated plasma levels of VLDL as well. Hence, these patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL; and low levels of LDL and HDL. 

Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive/pruritic xanthomas on the back, buttocks, and extensor surfaces, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. On funduscopic examination, the retinal blood vessels may appear opalescent, known as lipemia retinalis. The diagnosis should be suspected if the fasting triglyceride levels are greater than 500 mg/dL.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: The nucleus of which of the following cranial nerves is located deep to the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. 

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve. Columns are formed by groups of facial neurons, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurons innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature. 

The fourth ventricle is located between the brainstem and the cerebellum. The rhomboid fossa is a diamond-shaped depression seen on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The superior and the inferior parts of the floor are triangular in shape. It is divided by a longitudinal median sulcus into two halves. Each half is again divided into the medial and lateral regions.

 

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: A routine ultrasound done at 20 weeks period of gestation in a 31-year-old G1P0 woman revealed an anomaly. The patient comes to you with the following ultrasound film for a second opinion. Which congenital anomaly would you discuss when counseling the couple?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a primigravida who has come for an ultrasound at 20 weeks period of gestation showing a shower cap sign and open calvarium is suggestive of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of cranium and telencephalic structures above the skull base and orbits with normal facial portions. Anencephaly and spina bifida are common in the first birth, while the incidence of other malformations is high with increasing parity.

In USG, the cranial contour may appear abnormal in the first trimester and resemble a “shower cap” in the late first or early second trimester. The face often appears triangular. Sagittal images demonstrate a lack of an ossified cranium. Anencephaly is uniformly lethal. In the first half of pregnancy, the diagnosis is made by elevated alpha-fetoprotein in amniotic fluid. Diagnosis is confirmed by sonography.

The below image shows the shower cap sign and open calvarium in anencephaly. 

Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the frog-eye sign. The images given below show open calvaria on antenatal ultrasound and frog-eye sign.

Complications of anencephaly include

  • Hydramnios
  • Malpresentation—face or breech
  • Premature labor, especially when associated with hydramnios
  • The tendency of postmaturity
  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Obstructed labor, if the head and shoulders try to engage together because of a short neck

Option B- Intrauterine death is defined as antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. The earliest diagnosis is possible with sonography. Due to the liquefaction of brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, irregular overlapping of cranial bone termed spalding sign occurs. It appears 7 days after death. 

The image below shows the spalding sign.

Option C- Cystic hygroma is venolymphatic malformation that is characterized by fluid-filled sacs that extend from the posterior neck. Up to 70 percent of cystic hygromas are associated with aneuploidy. When cystic hygromas are diagnosed in the first trimester, trisomy 21 is the most common aneuploidy. Approximately 75 percent of aneuploid cases are X—Turner syndrome when diagnosed in the second trimester.

The image below shows cystic hygroma of the neck in the fetus.

Option D- Omphalocele is a congenital midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera or bowel herniate. The herniated abdominal contents are covered by a membranous sac as shown below.

 The image below shows an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. Which of the following would not be found in ascitic fluid analysis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of tuberculous peritonitis secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Paracentesis would reveal an exudate with high protein content and, therefore, a SAAG of <1.1g/L.

This patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss, and a radiograph showing a homogenous dense infiltrate in the right lung is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The presence of ascites and the above-mentioned signs and symptoms suggest tuberculous peritonitis.   

The various pathogenic mechanisms of gastrointestinal TB include direct seeding into the abdomen due to swallowing of the sputum, hematogenous seeding of tubercle bacilli from rupture of lymph nodes or intraabdominal organs, and ingestion of milk from cows infected with bovine TB. It presents with abdominal pain, swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, and a palpable abdominal mass. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, and anorexia are also present. The terminal ileum and cecum are the most commonly involved sites. 

The presence of fever, abdominal pain, and ascites should raise the suspicion of tuberculous peritonitis. The clinical presentation may be similar to Crohn's disease if the intestinal wall is involved, leading to ulcerations and fistulae. 

Paracentesis reveals an exudate with high protein content, lymphocytosis, and elevated levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Elevated ADA levels have very high sensitivity for tuberculous peritonitis. Standard anti-tubercular therapy is recommended for ascites caused by tuberculous peritonitis. If the etiology of the ascites is uncertain, laparoscopy with peritoneal biopsy for culture and histology remains the gold standard.

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text:
A woman who survived a tsunami 10 days back presents with repeated memories, flashbacks of getting tossed in the waves, and distressing dreams about the incident. She now fears going to the beaches again and tries to avoid the memories and people who were present during the incident. She feels like she is in a daze. She appears quiet, but there are anger outbursts. She has difficulty sleeping and has an exaggerated startle response. Which of the following statements are correct regarding her condition?

1. The diagnosis is acute stress disorder.

2. The diagnosis is post-traumatic stress disorder.

3. The first line of treatment is cognitive behavioral therapy.

4. The first line of treatment is risperidone.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes acute stress disorder. The first line of treatment for acute stress disorder is psychotherapy. So, option C is the right answer.

Diagnosis of acute stress disorder:

  • A person has exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violation.
  • Presence of nine or more of the following symptoms
    • Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories 
    • Recurrent distressing dreams related to the event
    • Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring.
    • Intense psychological distress
    • Inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or love feelings
    • An altered sense of the reality of one's surroundings or oneself 
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts
    • Efforts to avoid people, places, or conversations related to the incident
    • Sleep disturbances
    • Irritable behavior and angry outbursts
    • Hypervigilance
    • Increased startle response
  • The duration of the disturbance is 3 days to 1 month after trauma exposure
  • These disturbances cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning 
  • The disturbances are not attributable to any medical condition, medications, or alcohol.

The first line of treatment for acute stress disorder is psychotherapy.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as sertraline and paroxetine may be given.

In post-traumatic stress disorder, the patient has similar symptoms to an acute stress disorder, but the duration of the disturbance is more than 1 month.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man often remains alone, has few friends, always dresses in black, and prefers solitary activities. He says that he can read people's minds and believes in cleansing his aura by energizing crystals. Which cluster of personality disorders does this person belong to?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the patient's odd and eccentric beliefs and magical thinking is suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder. Schizotypal personality is classified as a cluster A personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behavior. They usually lack friends due to poor interpersonal relationships. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition, beliefs that they have superpowers, etc. They have peculiar speech and eccentric appearances. They can be differentiated from schizophrenia by the lack of psychotic features.

 

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: Cell growth can be stopped at some specific checkpoints in the cell cycle, as depicted in the given image. Which stage of the cell cycle demonstrates the primary point in the regulation of cell growth?
questions.solution:
The primary point in the regulation of cell growth is the end of G1 phase.

The sequence of events that results in cell proliferation is called the cell cycle. The cell cycle is regulated by activators and inhibitors called cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs).

The G1 restriction point refers to the stage in G1 where the cell is committed to advancing further into the cell cycle without requiring any more of the growth signal that initiated cell division. The G1-S checkpoint monitors DNA integrity before irreversibly committing cellular resources to DNA replication. Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2 regulate the G1-to-S transition by phosphorylating the Rb- retinoblastoma protein.

The G2-M is also a restriction point, but it checks for accurate genetic replication before the cell actually divides. When DNA irregularities are noted, the cycle is stopped and DNA repair mechanisms are activated. If repair cannot be done, cells either undergo apoptosis or enter a nonreplicative state called senescence through p53-dependent mechanisms.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma endometrium was treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic region?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovary is the most radiosensitive. 

The decreasing order of radiosensitivity is: ovary >rectum >bladder >vagina.

The radiosensitivity is higher in cases where the proliferation is high. In case of the ovary, it contains a high number of clonal cells since it is a reproductive organ. Thus, among the given options ovary is they most radiosensitive organ.

questions.text: A patient with fatigue and pallor is found to have severe anemia. You decide to do a PRBC transfusion. What is the cannula size and duration of transfusion?

choices.text: With a 18-20G needle, within 4 hours of receiving at the patient's side
With an 18-20G needle, within 30 minutes of issue from the blood bank
With a 20-22G needle, within 4 hours of receiving at the patient's side
With an 18-20G needle, within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank

questions.solution:
A patient undergoing packed red blood transfusion (PRBC) should receive it with an 18-20G needle within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank.

The guidelines for blood transfusion are as follows.

  • Obtain large-bore intravenous access with an 18 gauge or larger cannula.
  • Each unit should be transfused within 4 hours of issue from the blood bank (removal from controlled temperature storage).
  • A second IV access should be secured in case the patient needs additional IV medications.
  • Normal saline is the only fluid that can be administered with blood products.
  • Red blood cell units left out of controlled temperature storage for more than 30 minutes should not be returned to storage for reissue.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in a patient with emphysema?
questions.solution:
In emphysema, the destruction of the alveolar walls brings down the diffusion area.

Changes in Emphysema

  • Due to the destruction of the alveolar walls, there is a decrease in surface/diffusion area.
  • Cardiac output will be normal.
  • Pulmonary artery pressure may be elevated because the destruction of alveoli leads to loss of surrounding capillaries which forces blood into remaining capillaries, which tends to increase pulmonary artery pressure.
  • Alveolar Pco2 will tend to increase due to difficulty in expiration.

Diffusion capacity of Lung for CO (DLCO):

  • In case of emphysema – Decreased diffusion (DLCO) because of decreased surface area (trypsin destroys respiratory membrane)
  • In case of fibrosis or pulmonary edema – Decreased diffusion (DLCO) because of increased thickness of membrane
  • In case of anemia – Decreased DLCO
  • Polycythemia, pulmonary hemorrhage – Increased DLCO.

questions.text:
Match the following scattergrams with their correlation coefficient.

A) 0
B) -0.5
C) +1
D) +0.5
questions.solution:
Correlation (denoted by r) is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer).

The correlation coefficient is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • +1 or -1 suggests the maximum possible strength of the correlation.
  • Values closer to 1 have greater strength of the correlation.
  • Correlation coefficients greater than +/- 0.5 are suggested as strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.

The sign indicates the direction of correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated, which implies that the variables are associated (Ex: Smoking and lung cancer have a positive correlation ).
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated, which implies that the variables are inversely associated with each other (Ex: Alcohol intake and Malaria have a negative correlation).
  • For example, both -0.88 and +0.88, represent the same strength of the correlation. However, +0.88 suggests a positive correlation, and -0.88 suggests a negative correlation.

 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A woman complains of sudden-onset pain in the right eye that is worse at night, along with redness and a decrease in vision. Slit-lamp examination findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is anterior uveitis. The image shows keratic precipitates in the cornea, which is a feature of acute anterior uveitis. The clinical history of unilateral eye pain that is worse at night is typically seen in this condition.

Keratic precipitates (KP) are deposits on the corneal endothelium and are composed of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. These precipitates are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uvea extending from the iris to the pars plicata.  

Inflammation leads to pseudo-rubeosis iridis (dilatation of the blood vessels) and exudation. A large amount of exudation causes the iris to become waterlogged with the sticky fluid and causes movement restriction. This is why there are sluggish pupillary reactions. The extravasated fluid is also an irritant that causes the ciliary muscle fibers to contract, leading to pupillary constriction.

The iris loses its clear and defined pattern and becomes "muddy." The exudate also spills into the anterior chamber. This causes the aqueous to become turbid and is seen as a hazy, milky "flare" on slit-lamp examination. This is known as aqueous flare and is the earliest sign of anterior uveitis. Other characteristic clinical features are Koeppe and Busacca nodules (iris nodules)and the formation of posterior synechiae.

Other options:

Options A and C: Acute congestive glaucoma and acute conjunctivitis are both differential diagnoses for acute anterior uveitis. However, they do not have the characteristic feature of keratic precipitates.

Option D: Concussion cataract occurs due to aqueous imbibition and injury of lens fibers during ocular trauma. 

Related Pearl: Different types of keratic precipitates (KPs)

KPs
Notable points
Seen in
Mutton-fat KPs
Composed of epithelioid cells and macrophages
Granulomatous uveitis
Granular KPs
Composed of lymphocytes
Non-granulomatous uveitis
Fine KPs or
Stellate/Star shaped KPs
Form endothelial dusting
Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis
Old KPs
Sign of healed uveitis
 --------
Red KPs
 --------

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with postural dizziness and fatigue. On examination, her skin shows hyperpigmentation on her lips, palmar creases, knuckles, and in the paraumbilical region. On examination, her pulse is 96 bpm and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Which of the following abnormalities is least likely to be seen in her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Addison’s disease. Hyponatremia is a characteristic biochemical abnormality seen in most patients at presentation.

Primary adrenal insufficiency, or Addison's disease, occurs due to the impaired secretion of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids, resulting in various clinical manifestations.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

  • Features of hypoaldosteronism- 
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Acute kidney injury due to volume depletion
    • Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
  • Features of decreased cortisol-
    • Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, fever (increased IL-1)
    • Postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
    • Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
  • Decreased androgens-
    • Loss of libido, loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Features of elevated ACTH- hyperpigmentation

 Common causes of Addison’s disease:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries
  • Autoimmune (idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries
  • Metastasis to adrenal glands

Diagnosis - Cosyntropin stimulation test, plasma ACTH and cortisol levels, plasma renin and aldosterone levels

Treatment - Glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen replacement therapy

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the emergency room with a severe headache. On examination, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg. An intracerebral bleed is suspected. Which of the following locations is the bleed most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen. Patients typically present with severe headache. The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the usual locations of ICH: 

  •   Basal ganglia hemorrhage (especially the putamen)
  •   Thalamic hemorrhage
  •   Pontine hemorrhage
  •   Cerebellar hemorrhage 

The investigation of choice in stroke is non-contrast CT.

The following image shows bleeding in the basal ganglia on a non-contrast CT brain:

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Description Cause
Intentional tremor Cerebellum Only on activity 
  • Trauma
  • Stroke

  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism
Hyperkinetic tremor Sympathetic overactivity  Precipitated by emotion , stress
  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism 
Asterixis Cortex Inability to sustain a muscle contraction while performing a complex motor movement
  • Hepatic encephalopathy 
Chorea Caudate nucleus and putamen  Rapid jerky movement
  • Rheumatic chorea
  • Huntington chorea
  • Drug induced 
Hemibalismus Subthalamic nucleus Unilateral wild flinging violent movement of large proximal joints
  • Vascular>degenerative 
Athetosis Basal ganglia- Globus Pallidum Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
  • Vascular 
  • Degenerative 
  • Infiltrative

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with sudden-onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Damage to which of the following structures is likely to have resulted in diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden onset of loose, colorless, rice water stools with a sweetish odor, vomiting, and muscle cramps is likely to have cholera, with damage to zonula occludens (tight junction).

Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is produced by Vibrio cholerae and has the ability to increase mucosal permeability by reversibly affecting the structure of tight junctions.

The mechanism of action of cholera toxin is given below:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of A and B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit is the active part.
  • A subunit causes activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, which causes secretions of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the small intestinal lumen. This leads to watery diarrhea, which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate.

The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride. All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the ensuing massive water and electrolyte depletion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male farmer presents with multiple discharging cervical sinuses. Findings of Gram staining are shown below. Which part of the body does the organism most commonly infect?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the sunray appearance on Gram staining are suggestive of actinomycosis. The organism most commonly infects the mouth. 

Actinomycosis is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria Actinomyces. It causes a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain granules composed of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. It can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses. 

The four main clinical types:

  • Oral - Cervicofacial actinomycosis is the most common site- tissue swelling, abscess, mass, or ulcerative lesion.
  • Thoracic actinomycosis - Chest pain, fever, and cough with purulent sputum are common with the involvement of the parenchyma and pleural space.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- Often follows a ruptured appendix or an ulcer presenting as an abscess or mass.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.

Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures (sunray appearance). Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies as shown below.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

Treatment involves prolonged administration of penicillin for 6–12 months. Clindamycin or erythromycin is effective in penicillin-allergic patients.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of her hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. She has been treated with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine, but the disease is still progressing. Which of the following would be the next most appropriate step in further management?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and image are suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in the management of rheumatoid arthritis when the patient is not responding to methotrexate alone. Biologicals such as anti-TNF-alpha agents are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. But, before starting anti-TNF alpha agents, latent tuberculosis must be ruled out with an IGRA test or PPD.

Additionally, viral hepatitis B and C, complete blood counts, and liver function tests should be done before initiating anti-TNF agents.

Joints commonly affected in rheumatoid arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrical involvement) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints

DMARDS, glucocorticoids, and biologicals are used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA):

Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs): They are the mainstay of treatment. Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low-to-moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, 1-2 week bursts of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules. They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

  • Anti-TNF-alpha agents: Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, and certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.
  • Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist
  • Tocilizumab: IL-6 antagonist
  • Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells
  • Rituximab: Anti CD-20
  • Tofacitinib: JAK3 inhibitor

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Condition/Location Nerve

A. Guyon canal

 1. Radial nerve

B. Carpal tunnel

 2. Ulnar nerve

C. Thoracic outlet syndrome

 3. Median nerve

D. Saturday night palsy

 4. Tibial nerve

E. Tarsal tunnel syndrome

 5. Lower part of brachial plexus
questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are as follows:

A. Guyon canal

 2. Ulnar nerve

B. Carpal tunnel

 3. Median nerve

C. Thoracic outlet syndrome

 5. Lower part of brachial plexus

D. Saturday night palsy

 1. Radial nerve

E. Tarsal tunnel syndrome

 4. Tibial nerve

Option A: Guyon’s canal is a fibro-osseous canal, approximately 4 cm long in the adult, on the anteromedial aspect of the wrist under the superficial part of the flexor retinaculum. The ulnar nerve passes in Guyon’s canal along with the ulnar artery and can be compressed here.

Option B: Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common entrapment mononeuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the fibro-osseous carpal tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum. The palmar branch of the median nerve is spared because it does not pass through the carpal tunnel.

Option C: A cervical rib compressing the subclavian artery and the lower part of the brachial plexus is known as thoracic outlet syndrome. The patients complain of pain, paresthesia, and pallor of the affected upper limb.

Option D: A compressive neuropathy of the radial nerve due to prolonged, direct pressure onto the upper medial arm or axilla is called Saturday night palsy.

Option E: Tarsal tunnel refers to the tunnel-shaped medial end of the tarsal sinus. The flexor retinaculum may compress the tibial nerve or either of its branches (medial and lateral plantar nerves) in this tunnel and is most commonly due to a space-occupying lesion such as a ganglion.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

 Nerve

    Test

    Muscle
 Ulnar   nerve

 1.Book test

 2.Card test

 3.Froment's sign

 4.Egawa test

 1.Adductor   pollicis

 2.Palmar   interossei

 3.Flexor pollicis   substitutes for   adductor pollicis

 4.Dorsal   interossei
 Median   nerve

 1.Ape thumb

 2.Pen test

 3.Pincer grasp   (Kiloh Nevin   Sign)

 4.Pointing index   (ochners  clasp/Benediction   test)

 1.Thenar   muscles

 2. Abductor   pollicis brevis

 3. Flexor   digitorum   profundus+   Flexor pollicis   longus (Ant.   interosseous   nerve)

 4.Flexor   Digitorum   superficialis+   Lateral half of   Flexor   digitorum   profundus
 Radial   nerve

 1.Thumb and   finger drop

 2. Wrist drop

 1.Extensors(Post.   interosseous   nerve)

 2.Extensors of   wrist.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants can be safely used in this patient with a serum bilirubin level of 6 mg/dL and a serum creatinine value of 4.5 mg/dL ?
questions.solution:
Cisatracurium can be safely used in this patient with elevated bilirubin levels and renal dysfunction because its clearance is independent of liver and kidney function.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous, non-enzymatic, chemical degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium and vecuronium are metabolized significantly by the liver. Hence cannot be used in hepatic dysfunction. Doxacurium is partially metabolized by the kidneys so its action is prolonged in patients with renal failure.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with fever and colicky right upper quadrant pain and tenderness in the same area. After further investigations, a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made. The patient is taken for the procedure shown in the below image. Which of the following physiological changes is not expected during this procedure?

CVP- Central venous pressure

FRC- Functional residual capacity

ICP-Intracranial pressure
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and the pH during the procedure decreases due to the absorption of CO2, which in turn causes metabolic acidosis.

Laparoscopic surgeries are performed by introducing a rigid laparoscope through a port into the peritoneal cavity. Carbon dioxide is insufflated into the abdominal cavity to create a pneumoperitoneum. The other laparoscopic instruments used for dissection are introduced via other surgically created ports.

There are two methods for establishing abdominal access during laparoscopic surgeries. One is the direct puncture technique, and the other is the direct peritoneal access technique.

There is evidence to show that laparoscopic surgery has short-term benefits over open surgery. Laparoscopic surgery has a better outcome with regard to postoperative pain, length of stay, and earlier return to normal activities.

The physiological changes during laparoscopic surgery occur mainly due to two reasons:

  1. creation of pneumoperitoneum
  2. position of the patient during surgery.

Physiological Effects of Laparoscopy

  

Cardiovascular

• ↑ Intra-abdominal pressure leads to ↑ CVP, ↑ PCWP, ↑SVR, and ↑ MAP, which further ↓ Preload and ↑ Afterload, ultimately decreasing cardiac output

Pulmonary

• Cephalad shift of diaphragm decreases FRC, chest wall compliance, and tidal volume increasing the work of breathing

• Hypercapnia leading to an increase in respiratory rate further adds to this.

Renal

• Increased IAP decreases renal flow, decreases GFR, and reduced urine output.

• Raised pCO2 leads to RAAS stimulation. No long-term change in GFR/UO.

Gastrointestinal
  • Decreased perfusion to intestines and stomach (as a result of increased IAP) decreases pH
  • Decreased portal and hepatic flow lead to elevation of LFTs.

Peripheral vascular

• Incidence of DVT, PE is generally lower post-laparoscopic procedures probably secondary to improved prophylaxis

• Risk is increased with longer procedures and the reverse Trendelenberg position.

Central nervous system

The intracranial pressure rises due to compression of the lumbar venous plexus, hypercarbia causing cerebral vasodilation due to carbon dioxide (CO2) insufflation, and inferior vena cava compression inhibiting cerebral venous drainage.

questions.text: A young female patient was brought to the emergency room with severe gastrointestinal bleeding. The attenders inform the duty doctor that the patient was on warfarin medications. Her blood group is unknown. The duty doctor can transfuse fresh frozen plasma (FFP) from which of the following blood groups?
questions.solution:
AB fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed as in the above case, wherein the blood group of the patient is not known.

It is to be noted that in cases of active bleeding in a patient on warfarin therapy, prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is recommended over FFP. In case PCC is not available, FFP is used as in the above case.

FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from the secondary centrifugation of platelet-rich plasma. The plasma is rapidly frozen to –25°C or colder within 8 hours of collection and contains normal plasma levels of stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin, and Factor VIII at a level of at least 70% of normal fresh plasma.

Each unit of issued FFP contains a quantity of 200-300 mL.

FFP is capable of transmitting any agent present in cells or plasma, which was undetected by routine screening including HIV, hepatitis B and C, syphilis, and malaria.

Definite indications of FFP transfusion:

  • Replacement of a single coagulation factor deficiency, where a specific or combined factor concentrate is unavailable or contraindicated.
  • Immediate reversal of warfarin effect where prothrombin complex concentrate is unavailable.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Inherited coagulation inhibitor deficiencies where the specific concentrate is unavailable.
  • C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable

In an emergency, if crossmatched blood is unavailable:

  • Type O negative pRBCs are indicated for patients with exsanguinating hemorrhage because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens, and thus, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B, or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s blood.
  • AB plasma is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed because it does not contain antibodies against any antigens on RBCs.

questions.text: Which of the following G‐protein-coupled receptors does not act by opening potassium channels?
questions.solution:
The G‐protein-coupled receptor(GPCR) that does not act by opening potassium channels is angiotensin-1 receptor (AT1).

The hypertensive, renal, and hypertrophic effects of Angiotensin II are mediated by the activation of the AT1 receptor. AT1 receptors couple to Gq to activate the phospholipase-inositol triphosphate (IP3) - Ca2+ pathway which makes use of calcium and not potassium. 

IP3-DAG mechanism:

  • The hormone binds to a GPCR and via a Gq protein activates phospholipase C.
  • Phospholipase liberates Diacylglycerol (DAG) and Inositol triphosphate (IP3) from membrane lipids.
  • IP3 mobilizes Ca2+ from the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Together, Ca2+ and DAG activate protein kinase C that phosphorylates proteins and causes specific physiologic actions. 

Other options:

Option B: Muscarinic M2 receptors are Gi/Go type of GPCR mainly present in the heart and CNS. They reduce cAMP and activate inwardly rectifying K+ channels and inhibition of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition.

Option C: Dopamine D2 receptor couples with Gi/Go to decrease cAMP production and regulate K+ channels and Ca2+ channels.

Option D: The 5HT1-serotonin receptor family has five types, all of which preferentially couple to Gi or Go and inhibit adenylyl cyclase. They are also known to modulate K+ and Ca+ channels.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents with sudden onset severe chest pain. He is given sublingual nitroglycerin. Which property of this drug is being used in this case?
questions.solution:
Sublingual nitroglycerin is rapidly effective because it is non-ionic, and has high lipid solubility.

Oral mucosal absorption is beneficial for certain drugs even with a small surface area for absorption. The veins of the mouth drain directly to the superior vena cava bypassing the portal circulation. Because of this, any drug held sublingually and absorbed from that site does not undergo rapid intestinal and hepatic first-pass metabolism.

This is useful in the case of drugs like nitroglycerin because of its chemical properties. A drug that is in lipid-soluble, nonionized form is easily diffusible across a membrane and hence absorbed better. The ones that are ionized are relatively lipid insoluble and poorly diffusible across a membrane resulting in poor absorption.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and spontaneous epistaxis to the emergency room. His past history is significant for recurrent bleeding for the last 1 year. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. Which is the most common source artery that is involved in his nasal bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and the CT showing Holman Miller sign indicate nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Internal maxillary artery is the most common source of bleeding in this case.

Internal maxillary artery is the most common source artery of nasal bleeding followed by ascending pharyngeal artery and external, internal, and common carotid arteries.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that grows to form angiofibroma under the influence of testosterone. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis - most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech - due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion - due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

 

MRI can also be done that reveal soft tissue extensions.

Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels also come from the internal carotid system.

questions.text: A FAST examination does not involve the routine examination of which of the following regions?
questions.solution:
Perirenal region/retroperitoneum is not specifically looked for in FAST 

The sequential order in which FAST is performed: pericardial sac, the right upper quadrant (RUQ), left upper quadrant (LUQ), and pelvis.

4 ‘Ps’ are evaluated in sequence: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

FAST stands for focused assessment with sonography for trauma. It is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Following regions are scanned:
    • Subxiphoid: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with syncopal episodes while playing soccer and sprinting. He has a family history of cardiac death in several relatives. Physical examination reveals a murmur along the left sternal border that increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. An echocardiogram shows marked hypertrophy and abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. There is also left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient having recurrent episodes of syncope with a systolic murmur along the sternal border that increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver and has echocardiography findings of marked hypertrophy and abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOT). Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (nifedipine) cause vasodilation and are avoided in such patients as they can produce a fall in peripheral resistance, thus increasing LVOT obstruction.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Clinical features - While most patients are asymptomatic, some may develop the following symptoms: dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation.

HCM is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

  • Loudest along the left sternal border
  • Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:
    • Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators
    • Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  
  • Decreases in intensity when there is
    • Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration
    • Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors
    • Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

Diagnosis - 

  • ECG - findings include -
    • Prominent abnormal Q waves
    • P wave abnormalities 
    • Left axis deviation
    • Deeply inverted T waves 
  • Echocardiography -
    •  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
    • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
    • LVOT obstruction

Treatment -

  • Patients with LVOT obstruction - beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, and disopyramide may be used. Vasodilators and diuretics must be avoided in patients with LVOT obstruction.
  • Patients without LVOT obstruction with LVEF ≥50 percent - Initial monotherapy with either a beta-blocker or a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is started. Diuretics may be used as needed.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. The findings of the oral cavity examination are shown below. The toxin responsible for the clinical manifestations is encoded by phage in this bacteria. What is the mechanism by which these bacteria acquire the phage?
questions.solution:
This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2. This toxin is encoded by a phage, which is acquired by transduction. 

Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments: A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells, while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

Diphtheria toxin resides in a lysogenic bacteriophage. The strains that carry this phage are toxigenic. 

This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane. Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis. Complications like damage to the heart (myocarditis), kidney (tubular necrosis), liver, and adrenal glands can develop due to the toxin.

Neisser's or Albert's stain will show the bacilli with metachromatic granules situated at the poles of the bacilli. Tellurite blood agar is the selective culture medium.

It is treated mainly by neutralizing with antitoxin and antibiotics to arrest more toxin production.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
A patient who is a painter by profession presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and bluish-black discoloration of gums are observed. All of the following are features of this poisoning, except __________.

ALA - Delta-aminolevulinic acid

choices.text: Microcytic hypochromic anemia with basophilic stippling of erythrocytes seen in peripheral smear
Elevated levels of ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine
Elevated levels of porphobilinogen in blood

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of lead poisoning. Porphobilinogen is not elevated in blood in lead poisoning.  

Lead inhibits the enzymes delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase and ferrochelatase, which are involved in heme synthesis. ALA is converted to porphobilinogen by ALA dehydratase, which is inhibited by lead. So, porphobilinogen levels are decreased in lead poisoning.

Clinical features of chronic lead poisoning include facial pallor, anemia, basophilic stippling of red cells, blue line in the gums, and retinal stippling. In the later phase, the findings are colic abdominal pain, constipation, nerve palsy, encephalopathy, and disturbance of the genito-urinary and cardiovascular systems. Laboratory findings include the following:

  • An elevated serum lead level
  • An elevated level of protoporphyrin in blood and elevated ALA and coproporphyrinogen in urine
  • Microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling in peripheral smear due to ineffective heme synthesis

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: What is the rationale behind xenobiotic metabolism by CYP enzymes?
questions.solution:
The rationale behind xenobiotic metabolism by CYP enzymes is their conversion to an inactive metabolite.

Drugs are chemical substances foreign to the body called xenobiotics. Metabolism of xenobiotics is needed to render nonpolar, lipid-soluble compounds to polar, water-soluble, and lipid-insoluble ones so that they are excreted in the renal tubules without being reabsorbed (option A and B). The elimination of drugs has been divided into 2 phases:

  • Phase 1 reactions: which include oxidation, reduction, or hydrolytic reaction. CYPs- Cytochrome P family of enzymes play a major role in phase 1 reactions. Reactions carried out by phase 1 enzymes usually lead to the inactivation of a drug. The addition of functional groups does little to increase the water solubility of the drug but alter its biological properties. 
  • Phase 2 reactions, in which enzymes catalyze the conjugation of the substrate (the phase 1 product) with a second molecule. Phase 2 enzymes facilitate the elimination of the drug by producing a metabolite with improved water solubility.
 

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal pain and 6 episodes of passing foul-smelling dark stool mixed with mucus and blood streaks. There is no history of fever and tenesmus. On examination, vitals are stable. The colonoscopic biopsy finding is given below. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the biopsy showing a flask-shaped ulcer is suggestive of amebic dysentery, and the causative agent is Entamoeba histolytica.

Intestinal amebiasis presents with large, foul-smelling stools, often with blood-streaked mucus as seen in this patient. The patient is usually afebrile and nontoxic. The amebic ulcer which is flask-shaped with a narrow mouth and neck and a large rounded base is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis. The ulcers are multiple, confined to the colon are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoid-rectal region.

Hepatic amebiasis is the most common extraintestinal complication of amebiasis causing liver abscesses. The centre of the abscess contains thick chocolate brown pus (anchovy sauce pus), which is liquefied necrotic liver tissue. lt is bacteriologically sterile and free of ameba.

Other options:

Option A - Giardia causes acute or chronic diarrhea with watery, semisolid, greasy, bulky, and foul-smelling stools. A large numbers of parasites attach to the bowel wall causing irritation and low-grade inflammation of the duodenal or jejunal mucosa causing crypt hypertrophy, villous atrophy or flattening, and epithelial cell damage.

Option C - Campylobacter jejuni causes gastroenteritis that is acute in the onset. Symptoms include crampy abdominal pain, profuse diarrhea that may be grossly bloody, headache, malaise, and fever.

Option D - Shigella causes bacillary dysentery, characterized by sudden onset of abdominal pain, fever, and watery diarrhea. Each bowel movement is accompanied by straining and tenesmus (rectal spasms), with resulting lower abdominal pain.

Related Pearl: Features of amoebic and bacillary dysentery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a chronic history of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done, and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture. Identify the condition and the special stain used to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and histology findings are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus, and mucin stain (Alcian blue) is used to identify goblet cells, which are indicative of the intestinal metaplasia occurring in the condition.

Barrett's esophagus is a type of metaplasia at the gastro-esophagal junction due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The squamous esophageal mucosa is converted to a columnal/intestinal type that is better suited to handle acid reflux. It is associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Grossly it appears as tongues of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. This metaplastic mucosa alternates with residual smooth, pale squamous (esophageal) mucosa. Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barrett's mucosa is shown in the image given below:

Other options:

Option A: Helicobacter pylori infection can be diagnosed with Warthin-Starry silver stain. It can also present with heartburn, but histology would show organisms within the surface mucus and inflammatory cell infiltrate below the epithelium in the antrum and not a columnar esophagus.

Option B: Barrett's esophagus and long-standing GERD can result in adenocarcinoma of distal esophagus. It would show increased intestinal-type glands with features of carcinoma.

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma commonly occurs in the middle esophagus, and a well-differentiated tumor would show intercellular bridges and nests of keratin pearls.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma

Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
