questions.text:
Match the following hormones to their respective receptor's target of action.
Hormone Target
1. Thyroid hormone A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
2. Insulin B. Adenylyl cyclase
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide C. Intracellular receptor
4. Norepinephrine D. Guanylyl cyclase
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option 3: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Thyroid hormones act on intracellular receptors (intracytoplasmic or intranuclear) to induce the transcription of selected mRNAs, thereby promoting protein synthesis. Other hormones with similar action include steroid hormones and retinoic acid.

Insulin activates the tyrosine kinase enzyme on the intracellular (cytoplasmic) portions of transmembrane receptors, thereby phosphorylating the receptor. Other hormones with similar action include EGF, PDGF, M-CSF

Atrial natriuretic peptide increases intracellular cGMP by activating the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. A similar mechanism of action is seen with nitric oxide (NO).

Norepinephrine acts on intracellular adenylyl cyclase enzyme via beta-1 (adenylyl cyclase activation to increase cAMP) and alpha-2 (adenylyl cyclase inhibition to decrease cAMP). It activates phospholipase C and increases the production of DAG, IP3, via alpha-1 receptors.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, who had attended his retirement party, came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a picture similar to the one given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Clinical features

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema- the whole retina looks white in color
  • Marked attenuation of arteries - thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein - cattle-track appearance

Fundoscopy may also show Hollenhorst plaque. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (frequent sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (hemoptysis), and kidneys (hematuria), and an x-ray shows the presence of a cavity in the right lung. These, along with laboratory features and positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA (cANCA) suggest that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

GPA is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels. Also, necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis is present in the condition.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, saddle nose, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present.

Antiproteinase 3-ANCA or antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (cANCA) is seen in 95% of patients and is a useful marker of disease activity.

Management is as follows:

  • Induction with cyclophosphamide and glucocorticoids for severe disease. This is stopped after 3-6 months and can be switched to rituximab, azathioprine, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil for the remission.
  • Induction with rituximab and glucocorticoids is also effective in severe disease.
  • For a non-severe disease, methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids is effective for induction as well as remission.

Other options:

Options A - In Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary-renal syndrome), anti-GBM autoantibodies are formed against the glomerular basement membrane. Younger patients present with hemoptysis, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria while older people present with isolated glomerulonephritis.

Option B - Microscopic polyangiitis mainly involves the small arterioles and venules. The presentation is similar to GPA. However, they do not have upper airway disease or pulmonary nodules. They have mainly MPO antibodies or P-ANCA positivity. The distinction can be made on a biopsy where microscopic polyangiitis would have vasculitis without granulomas. 

Option C - Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis that has palpable purpura over the buttocks and lower extremities, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children and the mechanism is immune complex deposition with IgA antibody.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
Vessels affected Small and medium vessel vasculitis Small vessel vasculitis
Principal organs involved

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

GIT

Skin (cutaneous vasculitis)

Nerves (Mononeuritis multiplex)

Upper respiratory tract

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

Eye

Skin

Upper airway involvement

 Less common

More common

(Sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, septal perforation)
Nodular cavities in the lungs Absent Present
ANCA pANCA (mainly) cANCA(mainly)
Granuloma Absent Present
Necrosis Present Present
Kidney Glomerulonephritis Glomerulonephritis

 

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-Smith SLE

questions.text: Urinary bladder can be injured in all the following operations, except _______.
questions.solution:
Urinary bladder injury is not commonly associated with inguinal lymph node dissection.

The urinary bladder may be injured in

  1. Inguinal or femoral herniotomy
  2. Hysterectomy
  3. Excision of the rectum

If the injury is recognized, the bladder must be repaired and catheter drainage maintained for 7 days.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure depicted below?
questions.solution:
The Kasai procedure, or Roux-en-Y hepato-portoenterostomy, is shown in the above image.

It is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia is a rare disease of neonates characterized by the inflammation and obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts. The incidence is estimated to be 1 in 5000 to 12,000 infants and the disease is progressive. It may be associated with other congenital malformations, such as splenic abnormalities like asplenia, absence of the inferior vena cava, and intestinal malformation.

Histopathology shows significant extrahepatic biliary obstruction with portal tract fibrosis, inflammatory cell infiltration, bile duct proliferation, and cholestasis with bile plugging.

The disease is classified according to the level of the most proximal biliary obstruction:

  • Type 1 biliary atresia has patency to the level of the common bile duct (CBD)
  • Type 2 biliary atresia has patency to the level of the common hepatic duct
  • Type 3, which accounts for a majority of the cases, occurs when the left and right hepatic ducts, at the level of the porta hepatis, are involved. 

Infants have symptoms of jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine right after birth. In advanced disease, infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, and ascites due to liver cirrhosis. If jaundice persists after 14 days of life in a term infant, the liver function needs to be assessed by determining direct or conjugated bilirubin levels, which will be elevated to more than 2.0 mg/dL in those with liver involvement. Other investigations to be done include serology for toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes (TORCH) and hepatitis B and C infections, α1-antitrypsin levels, and cystic fibrosis. Metabolic disorders, such as galactosemia and tyrosinemia, and endocrine abnormalities must also be ruled out.

Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of biliary atresia.

Other options:

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75–150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30–50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

Option C: Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy Here, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Whipple procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, can be performed either with the standard technique, which includes distal gastrectomy or with the preservation of pylorus. It is performed in familial adenomatous polyposis, carcinoma head of pancreas, etc.

questions.text: A patient who underwent kidney transplantation a month ago presented with headache, fever, and focal neurological deficits. He was diagnosed with a brain abscess. Nasal biopsy was done for further evaluation. Identify the causative agent and the stain used.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Gram stain depicting a cluster of branching, filamentous gram-positive rods, which are findings suggestive of Nocardia.

Nocardia spp. appear as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease positive. They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1–4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

Nocardiosis commonly occurs as an opportunistic infection. Risk factors include corticosteroid treatment, immunosuppression, organ transplantation, AIDS, and alcoholism. Pulmonary nocardiosis is the most common clinical manifestation. Clinical features are fever, chest pain, weight loss, cough, shortness of breath, and night sweats.

Extrapulmonary manifestation occurs in almost half of the patients with pulmonary nocardiosis. It presents as a subacute brain abscess with headache, fever, and focal neurological deficit.

The treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. 

Other options:

Option B: The image given below is a smear of modified acid-fast Kinyoun staining showing filamentous red-stained partially acid-fast rods suggestive of Nocardia.

 

Option C- Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. 

Option D: The image given below is a smear with Ziehl-Neelsen staining showing non-branching and acid-fast Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Acid fast Organisms

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

  • Mycobacterium leprae

  • Eggs of Taenia saginata
  • Eggs of Schistosoma mansoni
  • Oocyst of Cryptosporidium
  • Oocyst of Cyclospora
  • Oocyst of Cystoisospora

questions.text: A  pregnant woman at term gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements. A non-stress test was done and the cardiotocograph is given below. Which of the following conditions does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The above cardiotocography (CTG) image shows variable deceleration, which indicates umbilical cord compression.

Normal baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 110-160 bpm (beats per minute). Baseline FHR shows a beat-to-beat fluctuation in amplitude and frequency ranging from 5-25 bpm. This is called baseline variability. Whenever the fetus moves, there is a transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm lasting for 10- 15 seconds. This is called acceleration. Acceleration and normal baseline variability (5-25 bpm) is a sign of a healthy fetus.

Deceleration is the decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s. Following are the various types of decelerations seen on CTG and their clinical significance:

Feature Early deceleration Late deceleration Variable deceleration
The pattern of heart rate fall

Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate.

The maximum dip of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the contraction. 

Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate.

Onset, maximum dip, and recovery occur after the onset, peak, and recovery of contraction respectively.

Abrupt fall in the heart rate.   

Decelerations are variable in respect of the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions.
Time taken to reach the maximum dip of deceleration  >30seconds  >30seconds  <30 seconds
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental insufficiency, and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: During your labor postings, you notice the resident preferred the mediolateral episiotomy instead of the midline episiotomy. All of the following are true statements about mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy, except that _______.
questions.solution:
All of the following are true statements about the advantages of mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy except that blood loss is lesser (Option B). Mediolateral episiotomy is associated with a greater amount of blood loss than midline episiotomy.

Episiotomy: Surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy. 

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is the least Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema, oliguria, and frothy urine. He has no history of similar complaints. His urine was positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs, and no casts. His serum albumin was 2.4 gm/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of minimal change disease.

It most frequently manifests between the ages of 2 and 6 years. Edema is typically seen in children and is first noticed in the lower extremities and around the eyes. The absence of hypertension and extensive hematuria are key indicators of minimal change disease.

A urinalysis reveals 3+ or 4+ proteinuria. A protein: creatinine ratio of > 2.0 is required in spot urine. The level of serum creatinine is typically normal, but it may be unusually elevated if the intravascular volume contracts and reduces renal perfusion. The serum albumin concentration is less than 2.5 g/dL, and the levels of triglycerides and cholesterol are high. The levels of serum complement are normal. If the patient meets the typical clinical profile of MCNS, a kidney biopsy is not generally carried out.

Other options:

Option A: The typical sign of IgA nephropathy is episodic hematuria linked to the deposition of IgA in the mesangium. One of the most prevalent types of glomerulonephritis in the globe is IgA nephropathy. Recurrent episodes of macroscopic hematuria during or right after an upper respiratory infection, frequently accompanied by proteinuria, and persistent asymptomatic microscopic hematuria is the two most typical manifestations of IgA nephropathy. 

Option C: Membranous nephropathy peaks between the ages of 30 and 50, with a male-to-female ratio of 2:1. It is the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly and is rare in children. MGN is linked to malignancy, infection, rheumatic disorders such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4 diseases, or drug exposure. A worse prognosis is linked to the male gender, advanced age, hypertension, and the continuation of nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Option D: Interstitial nephritis is indicated by the presence of white blood cells and white blood cell casts along with low-grade hematuria and proteinuria. Some children with drug-induced tubulointerstitial nephritis may have eosinophils in their urine.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

questions.text:
Which of the following are clinical features that can occur in catatonia?

1. Agitation

2. Anancasm

3. Akathisia

4. Akinesia
questions.solution:
Agitation and akinesia are the clinical features of catatonia. Option C is the correct answer.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by striking behav­ioral abnormalities such as motoric immobility or excite­ment, negativism, echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement). This extreme immobility is known as akinesia.

 The clinical picture may include three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  6. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  7. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  8. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  9. Agitation: Not influenced by external stimuli
  10. Grimacing
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.

The catatonic disorder may occur due to:

  • Advanced mood or psychotic illnesses
  • Neurologi­cal disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus, and head trauma)
  • Infections (e.g., encephalitis)
  • Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia)
  • Drugs induced- like corticoste­roids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotics (i.e., neurolep­tic) agents.

Management: The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially, lorazepam, are effective in improving the symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

Anancasm is a synonym for obsession. It is seen in obsessive-compulsive personality disorder. 

Akathisia is a subject feeling of intense restlessness and is manifested as a constant movement. It occurs as an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. 

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A neonate presented with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body with hypoplasia of all limbs. An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy. An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital varicella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this infant with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body, hypoplasia of all limbs, and chorioretinitis.

Varicella zoster virus (VZV) is found to have in-utero transmission. Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by abnormalities in the newborn infant. The abnormalities are:

  • Cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like distribution
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Central nervous system abnormalities: ventriculomegaly, cortical atrophy, seizures, and mental retardation
  • Chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataracts
  • Renal system abnormalities: hydroureter and hydronephrosis,
  • Autonomic nervous system abnormalities: neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia
  • Low birth weight.
Diagnosis:
A history of gestational varicella and the presence of characteristic abnormalities in the newborn infant is mainly required for the diagnosis of congenital varicella syndrome. PCR can be used to identify VZV DNA in vesicular fluid or scabs from zoster lesions. VZV-specific IgM antibodies from cord blood can be used to diagnose. In the asymptomatic child, a positive VZV IgG antibody titer at 12-18 months of age is a reliable indicator of prenatal infection.

Other options:

Option A- Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is hearing loss. Diagnosis can be made by detection of CMV DNA in PCR obtained within 2-4 weeks of birth. IgM antibodies for CMV can also be used for diagnosis.

Option B- Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is due to the rubella virus. The most common finding among infants with CRS is nerve deafness. The most serious eye-finding is unilateral or bilateral cataracts. Cardiac abnormalities like patent ductus arteriosus (most commonly reported cardiac abnormality), lesions of pulmonary arteries, and valvular diseases are also seen. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option C- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose (depression of the nasal root) are some late findings.

Related Pearl: CNS infections and regions commonly affected

INFECTION REGION COMMONLY AFFECTED
Tubercular meningitis Basal part of the brain
Tubercular encephalitis Intra parenchymal granulomas
Meningovascular Neurosyphilis Base of the brain and meninges covering the cerebral convexities
Paretic neurosyphilis Frontal lobe
Tabes dorsalis(syphilis) Dorsal column of spinal cord
HSV encephalitis Temporal and frontal lobes
Varicella-zoster infection Dorsal root ganglia, Trigeminal ganglia
Cytomegalovirus Choroid plexus and paraventricular subependymal regions
Poliomyelitis Anterior horn cells of spinal cord
JC virus Oligodendrocytes
Rabies Hippocampus cerebellum
HIV Subcortical regions
Aspergillosis/ Mucormycosis Blood vessel walls, Intraparenchymal abscesses or granulomas
Cryptococcosis Intra parenchymal abscesses or granulomas(soap bubble appearance)
Toxoplasmosis Cerebral cortex(near grey matter-white matter junction)
Cerebral malaria Blood vessels of brain

 

Related Pearl: Hutchinson’s Triad

Hutchinson’s triad is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis.

Components are as follows:

  • Hutchinson's teeth
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Sensorineural deafness (not conductive deafness)

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child has delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability, with the following appearance (image A). On further examination, there is an enlarged tongue, cloudy cornea, and hepatomegaly. A radiograph of the hand is shown in image B. A girl born in their family also had similar symptoms and she died at 9 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler syndrome. The child is 2 years of age and has coarse facial features like a depressed nasal bridge, thick lips, and an open mouth with protruded tongue. The radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpals and phalanges. These features along with severe developmental delay, cloudy cornea, hepatomegaly, and intellectual disability suggest that the child has Hurler syndrome.

It is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Patients usually present between 6-24 months of age. They have

  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex- thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella
  • Cloudy cornea, glaucoma, retinal degeneration
  • Mixed hearing loss, etc

Other options

Option A- The Scheie syndrome is a milder form of MPS-I (MPS I-S ). The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option B- Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option D- Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features as type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS with X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a baby girl is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. All the other MPS are autosomal recessive.

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

questions.text: A patient with cough, fever, and weight loss was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following is incorrect about the drugs used to treat this patient?

choices.text: Rifabutin is more efficacious than rifampicin for pulmonary TB
Rifabutin has a longer half-life than rifampicin
Rifabutin has a lesser incidence of drug interactions than rifampicin
Rifabutin is more efficacious against MAC as compared to rifampicin

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is that rifabutin is more efficacious than rifampicin for pulmonary TB.

Rifampin binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a drug-enzyme complex and suppresses chain formation in RNA synthesis. Rifabutin is related to rifampin in structure and mechanism of action, but compared to rifampin, it is less active against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and more active against Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC).

The half-life of rifabutin is much longer (>30 hours) as compared to rifampin (<5 hours).

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes like CYP3A4. As a result, it hastens the metabolism of drugs including OCPs, steroids, warfarin, phenytoin, and some HIV drugs that are metabolized by this microsomal enzyme. Rifabutin is a less-potent inducer of CYPs than rifampin.

Amongst rifamycins, the order of drug interactions is given as rifampicin > rifapentine> rifabutin. Hence, rifabutin is used when other drugs are used to decrease the likelihood of drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who was a chronic smoker came with complaints of swelling in the lip, as shown below. On examination, an ulcerative mass was seen and a submental lymph node was palpable. Which of the following is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Women above 60 years of age are commonly affected
Vermilion border of the upper lip is the common site
Exposure to chemicals like benzene is a common cause

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of lip cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men above 50 years of age. Exposure to the sun and smoking are the main risk factors of lip cancer. More than 90% of lip cancers are squamous cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip, followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. But the commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. The mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. There is a loss of sensation on the skin over the chin due to the involvement of mental nerves. Submental and submandibular nodes are frequently involved.

The early-stage disease can be treated by surgery or radiation therapy. Post-surgical irradiation is indicated in advanced-stage disease. For defects of more than one-third of the lip, surgical excision followed by lip augmentation surgery is needed.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presented with mild pain in the lower abdomen. She has had 2 full-term normal deliveries earlier. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. On pelvic examination, you find a palpable mass in the adnexa. On the USG pelvis, you find a 6 cm ovarian cyst, which is clear and unilocular. What should be your next best step?
questions.solution:
A clear ovarian cyst detected at 3 weeks after the last menstrual period, with minimal symptoms and a size of 6 cm, in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely to be a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to observe and follow up for the cyst after 2–3 months.

Functional cysts may be follicular cysts, lutein cysts, multiple functional cysts, or corpus luteal cysts. The size of the cysts should be at least 3 cm but not more than 7 cm.

  • Follicular cysts: They can be single or multiple. They may vary in size but generally do not exceed 5.0 cm in diameter. They form as a result of the failure of absorption of the fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. They are usually asymptomatic unless there is a hemorrhage in the cyst. Most follicular cysts disappear spontaneously within 4-8 weeks.

  • There are 2 types of Lutein cysts:

    • Corpus luteum/ Granulosa lutein cysts: They are functional and non-neoplastic. Persistent corpus luteum cysts may cause local pain, tenderness, or delayed menstruation. These cysts are often palpable clinically.
    • Theca lutein cysts: These cysts can sometimes enlarge to several centimeters in diameter. They are usually bilateral and filled with straw-colored fluid.

Treatment:

A simple unilocular cyst less than 7 cm in the reproductive age group is often a functional cyst. It should be observed. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously over 4-6 months. A repeat ultrasound is needed to check for a resolution. Oral combined pills may be prescribed for 3-4 months in women of reproductive age as this may help in its resolution.

A benign ovarian tumor of more than 7 cm requires removal. Open laparotomy is preferred to laparoscopic excision.

A simple unilocular cyst measuring less than 5 cm in a postmenopausal woman - It can be observed with repeated ultrasound and CA-125 every 3 months. A persistent cyst requires removal via laparoscopy or laparotomy.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a history of back pain. He gives a history of pulling a muscle while lifting heavy weights. On examination, there is exaggerated lumbar lordosis and you perform the test as shown in the image below. This is used to demonstrate _______.
questions.solution:
Thomas test is being performed in the image above. It is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. Here, the affected hip is extended while the contralateral hip is held flexed, flattening and immobilizing the lumbar spine.

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered a positive test as normally this is not possible.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a laceration on his left forearm.  On examination of the wound, it is found to have an irregular edge and depth. Which of the following is the most appropriate technique to be used to achieve the most accurate approximation of the wound?
questions.solution:
Mattress suturing, seen in image 3, would yield the best approximation when the wounded edges and depth are irregular.

Mattress sutures: They can be vertical or horizontal and are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then, the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again, as seen in the figure. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially in settings where the edges are not easily approximated.

The following image shows the mattress suture technique: 

 

In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound must be 'x'. Distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

The following image shows interrupted suture:

 

Continuous suture technique: The first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached. Care should be taken to maintain the tension of the suture to avoid excessive tension or leaving it too slack; hence, the use of an assistant is warranted. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures:

 

Subcuticular sutures: 

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound, and then, they are gently pulled together. This causes an approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured with the ends of absorbable sutures when used. When non-absorbable sutures are used, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

The following image shows the subcutaneous suture technique:

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution:
In the pelvic inlet, the obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter.

Anteroposterior Diameter of pelvic inlet:

True conjugate: Also called anatomical conjugate, is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis and measures 11 cm.

Obstetric conjugate: It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis. It is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet and measures 10 cm.

Diagonal conjugate: It is the distance between the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. It measures 12 cm. Obstetric conjugate is derived by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate depending upon the height, thickness and inclination of the symphysis pubis.

Pelvic inlet contraction is considered when the obstetric conjugate is <10 cm or the greatest transverse diameter is <12 cm or the diagonal conjugate is <11 cm.

The bispinous diameter measures 10.5 cm which is a transverse diameter of midpelvis plane. It measures between the two ischial spines.

questions.text: A boy who had a cut injury while playing with scissors comes to you for a follow-up. The wound now has new collagen fibrils, increased blood vessels, and a thick layer of growing epithelium. What is the age of his wound?
questions.solution:
The age of this boy's wound is around 5 days.

Histological changes in wounds. Stages of healing in an incised wound.

Time after injury Histological changes
30 minutes-4 hours

Margination of leucocytes in blood vessels

Mast cells lose their granules

Fibrin appears in the wound
4-12 hours

Leucocyte infiltration (mostly polymorphs)

Tissue edema

Start of epithelial regeneration
12-24 hours

Mononuclear leukocytes increase

Epidermis begins to spread across the wound
24-72 hours

Leukocyte infiltration reaches a peak at 48 hours

Granulation tissue appears
3-6 days

Collagen formation

Neovascularisation
10-15 days

Collagen reaction subsides

Vascularity decrease

Cell population drops
2 weeks - several months

Consolidation of healing tissue

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.

The reaction catalyzed by phosphoglucomutase is reversible so that

  • In glycogenesis: Glucose-6-phosphate is isomerized to glucose-1-phosphate
  • In glycogenolysis: Glucose-6-phosphate can be formed from glucose-1-phosphate

Glycogen synthase is an enzyme of glycogenesis. Alpha-1,6-glucosidase and glycogen phosphorylase are enzymes of glycogenolysis.

questions.text: Reverse transcriptase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. Which of the following uses reverse transcriptase?
questions.solution:
Among the given viruses, the hepatitis B virus (HBV) uses reverse transcriptase enzyme. The viral DNA polymerase has both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent reverse transcriptase functions.

The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus with an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. The viral genome consists of two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand) is incomplete, resulting in partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded DNA. The steps in replication of HBV can be summarized as follows:

  • The virus first attaches to the host and gets uncoated.
  • The partially double-stranded DNA is converted to covalently closed circular (ccc) DNA in the nucleus.
  • The cccDNA serves as the template for the production of HBV mRNAs and pre-genomic RNA.
  • The pre-genomic RNA is encapsidated by newly synthesized HBcAg core particles.
  • Within the encapsidated core, RNA serves as a template for the HBV reverse transcriptase, which is a part of the polymerase gene to synthesize negative-strand DNA. Positive-strand DNA synthesis starts but does not proceed to completion within the core, resulting in a variable-length positive-strand DNA.
  • Core particles containing these DNA replicative intermediates acquire HBsAg-containing envelopes to complete the process.

questions.text: Match the following agarose gel electrophoresis pattern with the type of cell death:
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-Control; 2-Apoptosis; 3-Necrosis

The given image is an agarose gel electrophoresis of DNA extracted from culture cells.

  • Lane 1 represents control.
  • Lane 2 represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. This pattern is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. A DNA ladder is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA between nucleosomes to generate fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs).
  • Lane 3 represents a smear pattern seen in the case of necrosis. In necrosis, DNA is usually not cut in an orderly manner due to the activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.

questions.text: Thoracic CT of a patient who had a history of road traffic accident is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows dark zones within the pleural cavity of the right lung, which is suggestive of a right pneumothorax and collapsed lung. Lung anatomy is not clearly seen and is masked by dark zones.

Pleural effusion refers to the presence of fluid within the pleural cavity. A hemothorax refers to the presence of blood within the pleural cavity. Empyema refers to the presence of pus in the pleural cavity. In all these cases, there is hyperdensity noted in the pleural cavity.

The below image shows empyema which appears hyperdense.

questions.text: A lady presents with bluish discoloration in the right eye and the surrounding periorbital skin since birth. She says that it has been increasing in size over the years. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a lady presenting with a bluish discoloration in the right eye and the surrounding periorbital skin since birth, which has been increasing in size over the years, is suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis distributed along with the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Most of the lesions occur at birth or during the first year of life. The lesion increases in size and number over the years, and the second peak of onset can also occur during puberty. These lesions do not disappear with time. Females are more commonly affected.

Management includes Q-switched lasers and cosmetic camouflage.

Complications include meningeal melanocytoma of the brain and malignant melanoma involving the meninges, choroid, iris, or orbit. In some rare cases, cutaneous melanoma can also develop.

Other options: 

Option A: Mongolian spots are slate blue areas in the lumbosacral region that spontaneously regress before puberty.

Option B: Becker's naevus is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It is often hairy. The onset is around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens, especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest

Option C: Naevus of Ito is unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular distribution.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

 

The following images show the findings in -

  • Rosacea

 

  • Butterfly-shaped malar rash in SLE

questions.text:
A patient with pulmonary hypertension comes for a vasoreactivity test. What drugs can be used if the test is negative?
  1. Bosentan
  2. Amlodipine
  3. Sildenafil
  4. Latanoprost
  5. Riociguat
questions.solution:
The drugs used for pulmonary hypertension if vasoreactivity test is negative are 1, 3, and 5.

Bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist, sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5) inhibitor, and riociguat is a soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulator used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension

Vasoreactivity testing involves the administration of inhaled nitric oxide, IV epoprostenol, or adenosine. The test is considered positive if the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAH) decreases.

  • Positive vasoreactivity test: Calcium channel blockers (CCB) are indicated. Nifedipine, diltiazem or amlodipine are used.
  • Negative vasoreactivity test: Drugs other than CCBs are used.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that is a PGF2α derivative. It reduces intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is not used in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, neck stiffness, and projectile vomiting along with the altered sensorium. The image below shows the findings of India ink staining. What is the likely causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the stain findings are suggestive of cryptococcosis, and the causative organism is Cryptococcus neoformans.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options:

Option B: Candida albicans cause systemic infection in immunocompromised like those taking steroids or other immunosuppressive agents, malignancy, etc. CSF in Candida meningitis would show pseudohyphae and budding cells.

Option C: Aspergillus fumigatus cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients that presents as fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Microscopy shows uniform, branching septate hyphae using Gomori methenamine silver stain.

Option D: Fungi of the genus Mucor are zygomycetes, with broad, ribbon-like sparsely septate hyphae; they are responsible for rhinocerebral mucormycosis, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis in diabetic patients and immunocompromised individuals.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A young lady with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complains of lower abdominal pain. Her urine pregnancy test came positive, and her BP is 110/80 mmHg. A transvaginal scan was done, which revealed a 5 × 5 cm adnexal mass on the right side. What would be your plan of management?

choices.text: Give IV fluids, keep NPO, and observe for 4–5 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy, where the patient is hemodynamically stable. This scenario does not fall under the criteria for medical treatment since the ectopic mass is >4 cm; therefore, laparoscopic surgery is required.

Management of tubal ectopic pregnancy:

Expectant management is where only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution.

Indications:

  • Initial serum hCG level less than 1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestational sac size less than 4 cm 
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS

Medical management is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. It involves the systemic or local use of chemotherapeutic drugs: 

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly)
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-hCG

Medical management is likely to be successful when

  • Initial serum hCG level is <5,000 IU/L.
  • Ectopic mass is less than 4 cm.
  • Fetal cardiac activity is absent.
  • Intra-abdominal hemorrhage is absent.

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy and microsurgical laparotomy. 

Indications:

  • Cases not fulfilling the criteria of medical therapy
  • Cases where serum hCG levels are not decreasing despite medical therapy
  • Persistent fetal cardiac activity

Following conservative surgery or medical treatment, estimation of serum β-hCG level should be done weekly until the β-HCG values go down.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given image shows the trochlear nerve (CN IV). It is identified easily as it is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal surface of the brainstem. It supplies the superior oblique muscle. The actions carried out by the superior oblique muscle are intorsion, depression, and abduction. 

  • Lateral rectus is supplied by the abducens nerve (CN VI).
  • Medial rectus and inferior oblique are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).

questions.text: A surgeon resecting a mass suspicious for malignancy orders a frozen section biopsy. All of the following statements are true about this procedure, except that ___.

choices.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example
It is used for detecting positive margins after resection
It is used to confirm suspected metastasis
It gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of the tumor

questions.solution:
A frozen section done during the surgery of a carcinoma breast is not useful for a definitive diagnosis.

A frozen section provides rapid gross or microscopic diagnoses that can guide intra- or peri-operative management of a patient, including identification of an unknown pathologic process and tissue, evaluation of adequacy of margins, and identification of metastases.

A sentinel lymph node is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor. An examination of frozen sections of the sentinel lymph node performed during surgery can guide the surgeon to the appropriate therapy. In patients where there is no tumor involvement of the sentinel node, further axillary dissection can be avoided.
 
The quality of a frozen section slide is inferior to that of routinely processed material, reducing the accuracy and precision of diagnosis. Even though frozen section provides rapid diagnosis, it should not be used to replace paraffin-embedded tissue technique to get a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A person sustained an injury to the right eye with a tennis ball, following which he developed pain. On fundus examination, a milky white macula with a red spot is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Commotio retinae, or Berlin’s edema, is the most probable diagnosis.

It occurs following a blow to the eye. It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region.

Blunt trauma to the eye produces:

  • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.
  • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.
  • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at the foveola.

It may disappear after some days or may be followed by pigmentary changes. Given below is an image of Berlin's edema.

questions.text: A three-year-old boy was brought to the ENT outpatient department by his mother. She reports that for the past few days, the boy has had loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. She also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. Fibreoptic laryngoscopy findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a three-year-old child with stridor and hoarseness of voice and laryngoscopy showing a laryngeal papilloma is highly suggestive of respiratory papillomatosis/juvenile papillomatosis. It mostly affects the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. 

Respiratory papillomatosis/Juvenile papillomatosis:

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by the human papilloma DNA virus types 6 and 11. 
  • Mothers with vaginal human papillomavirus are presumed to transmit the disease at birth to their children.
  • It most commonly involves the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. They can also appear in the subglottic, trachea, and bronchi.
  • Clinical features:
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
    • Stridor
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy which shows characteristic warty growths and is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.
  • Tumour can be removed under a microscope with cup forceps or a debride similar to the one used in endoscopic nasal surgery in the absence of CO2 lasers.
  • Interferon-alpha-2α and 13-cis-retinoic acid have shown promising results but have several side effects.

Other options:

Option A:  Infantile hemangioma presents in the first 6 months of life involving the subglottic area. It presents with stridor and usually, resolves spontaneously.

Option C: Vocal cysts: These are retention cysts due to blockage of seromucinous glands of the laryngeal mucosa. They occur in the false vocal cords.

Option D: Vocal polyp is caused by sudden shouting which results in hemorrhage and edema of the vocal cord. Affected individuals present with hoarseness of voice and diplophonia(double voice). Other factors associated with it are allergy and cigarette smoking. It presents as a benign swelling on the free edge of the vocal cord.

questions.text: A patient with benign hypertrophy of the prostate was admitted to the hospital for 3 weeks. He subsequently developed a suspected catheter-associated urinary tract infection. The catheter tip was sent for culture on blood agar, and the appearance of the culture is shown below. All the following statements related to the causative organisms are true, except _______.

choices.text: The characteristic growth shown in the image is also seen on MacConkey agar
The characteristic growth shown in the image is inhibited on the CLED medium
In a urinary tract infection caused by this organism, the urine is alkaline

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the image showing swarming motility are suggestive of Proteus infection, which does not show swarming on MacConkey medium.

Proteus mirabilis is an important urinary and nosocomial pathogen. They are commonly responsible for urinary and septic infections and are related to urinary tract infections in patients undergoing long-term catheterization. They hydrolyze urea to release ammonia, which makes the urine become alkaline and promotes stone formation.

On MacConkey medium, smooth, colorless colonies are formed as they are non-lactose fermenters. Swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.

They show swarming motility on blood agar due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar. This is inhibited by chemicals, such as phenyl ethyl alcohol or CLED (cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient) medium (Also in presence of other substances like chloral hydrate, sodium azide, boric acid, and sulphonamide).

 

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes

Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husband is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti-D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization. Which of the following is false about anti-D immunoprophylaxis?

choices.text: The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is 60 days
First dose is given at 28 weeks of gestation to D-negative, unsensitized Rh-negative women
Second dose is given within 72 hours of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive with direct Coombs’ test negative
300 μg of anti-D immune globulin can neutralize 15 mL of fetal RBCs

questions.solution:
The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is not 60 days. Hence, option A is false regarding anti-D immunoprophylaxis.

The half-life of anti-D immune globulin ranges from 16 to 24 days, depending on the preparation. (Option A) This is the reason why it is given in both the third trimester and following delivery. 

All D-negative, unsensitized women should receive anti-D Ig at approximately 28 weeks of gestation (Option B). The second dose is given within 72 hours of the delivery and the newborn is D-positive (Option C).

300 μg or 1500 IU is the standard intramuscular dose of anti-D Ig. It will protect the average-sized mother from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of whole fetal blood or 15 mL of fetal red cells (Option D). Kleihauer-Betke test is used to estimate the approximate volume of fetal blood that enters the maternal circulation.

The protocol for Rh isoimmunization is as follows:

questions.text: Ponderal index is ____.

choices.text: Square root of fetal length (cm)*100/fetal weight (kg)

questions.solution:
Ponderal index = Fetal weight in grams X 100/(fetal length in centimeters)3 (Option B)

A ponderal index (PI) is one of the anthropometric methods used to diagnose impaired fetal growth. The percentiles allow the discrimination between symmetric and asymmetric growth restriction in preterm and term infants. PI below 10th centiles is taken as fetal growth restriction. 

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density

questions.text: 2-year-old Neha has been having fever since yesterday and is refusing food. Parents became alarmed when she developed an abnormal barking cough today morning and have brought her to the casualty. On examination, the child looked exhausted and had visible chest retractions and stridor. The temperature was 39.6 degrees and SpO2 was 93% on room air. Chest X-ray reveals a 'steeple' sign. What is the treatment of choice in this child?

choices.text: Send a throat swab and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
Fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor and a steeple sign on chest radiograph are suggestive of acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The treatment of choice in this child is nebulization with racemic epinephrine. 

Epinephrine acts rapidly and provides immediate relief. It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure. This increases fluid resorption and reduces airway edema.

Westley Croup Severity Score: 

Feature  0 1 2 3 4 5
Stridor None With agitation At rest      
Air Entry Normal Decreased Markedly decreased      
Retractions None Mild Moderate Severe    
Cyanosis None       With agitation At Rest
Level of Consciousness Normal, including sleep         Disoriented

Overall score and severity

  • 0 to 2- mild
  • 3 to 7- moderate
  • 8 to 11- severe
  • 12 to 17- impending respiratory failure

Treatment of moderate to severe croup :

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization
  • Dexamethasone is indicated in all grades of croup and is given by the least invasive route (Oral>IM>IV)
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated in croup

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
