questions.text: A lady with an abdominal mass was investigated. On surgery, she was found to have bilateral ovarian masses with a smooth surface. Microscopy revealed mucin-secreting cells with signet ring shapes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Kruckenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It typically manifests in young girls or in children. It is typically unilateral, and like all solid tumors, it may be linked to ascites. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma. Cells are organized in clusters or alveoli that make up the tumor. The tumor cells are always accompanied by lymphocytes and large cells. 

Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in young girls between the age of 15 and 25 years. It is mostly unilateral. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as a yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by epithelium that resembles an endocervix They are usually unilateral and are associated with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumor ruptures, it may lead to the formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A researcher wants to do a study of blood levels of lipids among people who smoke and those who do not. But he is now concerned that smokers might differ from non-smokers in their diet, exercise, etc., as well. This concern is known as _______.
questions.solution:
The type of bias involved is a selection bias.

Bias refers to any systematic error in determining the association between exposure and disease. In a selection bias, the cases and controls selected may not be representative of the general population, due to systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. It is also called sampling bias.

In the given scenario, is now concerned that smokers might differ from non-smokers in their diet and exercise. This would mean the study population would not have a proper representation of cases in smoking and non-smoking group.

The controls may differ from the cases many factors. Matching is a process by which we select controls in such a way that they are similar to cases with regard to certain selected variables (e.g. exercising) which are known to influence the outcome of disease.

Other options:

Option A: Recall bias occurs as a result of the cases being more likely able to recall the existence of certain events or factors than the controls. For example, patients who have had a stroke would be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events that led to the episode than those who have not.

Option B: Berksonian bias applies to hospital cases and controls. It occurs because of the difference in rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases.

Option C: Interviewer's bias occurs when the person conducting the case-control study knows the hypothesis and who the cases are. This may lead to the interviewer questioning the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding the history of the causal factor.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with numerous hypopigmented and hypoesthetic skin lesions all over his trunk and extremities. Examination reveals a thickening of the ulnar and popliteal nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a case of borderline lepromatous leprosy. 

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin, cutaneous and peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. The most commonly affected peripheral nerves are the posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves. The most commonly involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve. 

Leprosy has a long incubation period, usually ranging from 2 to 12 years. It commonly presents as an area of numbness on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which could be a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.

Ridley-Jopling classification of leprosy:

    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)

 

Indeterminate (IL)

One or a few hypopigmented or faintly erythematous, ill-defined to well-defined macular lesions with mild to moderate impairment of touch and/or thermal sensations. No thickening of peripheral nerves.
Borderline tuberculoid (BT)

Macular or plaque-type lesions numbering three to nine or more and asymmetrically located on any part of the body, with variable sizes and contours. Satellite lesions may be present. Loss of sensation is less intense than it is in TT lesions.

Several peripheral nerves are likely to be enlarged in an asymmetrical pattern, with sensory and motor deficits. Increased susceptibility to develop Type 1 leprosy reaction.
Tuberculoid (TT) Well-defined, hypopigmented macule or as a raised, erythematous/brown/copper-colored plaque with a well-defined edge up to three in number. 

Complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensations over the lesion.

Larger corresponding cutaneous nerves are thickened in a limited number of case
Mid-borderline (BB)

An unstable form of leprosy. Multiple plaque lesions and macular lesions; lesions are of various shapes and sizes, are bilateral, and usually occur in a more or less symmetrical. Minimal loss of sensation over the lesions.

Many nerves may be thickened, and this effect may be asymmetrical.
Borderline lepromatous (BL)

Numerous bilateral, round or oval, macular, diffusely infiltrated, erythematous, or hypopigmented lesions with moderately defined borders. Some loss of sensation may be detected, particularly over older lesions.

Widespread but asymmetrical thickening of peripheral nerves
Lepromatous (LL)

Innumerable bilateral, symmetrically distributed, diffusely indurated, erythematous, copper-colored, or skin-colored patches or plaques. There is no loss of sensation over these lesions.

Bilateral earlobe thickening and eyebrow loss occur. Coarse induration on the face gives rise to leonine facies.

Involvement of peripheral nerves occurs late and is bilateral and symmetrical, with sensory loss in a “glove-and-stocking” distribution.

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

  • Characteristic skin lesions- hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with definite impairment of sensation.
  • Peripheral nerve involvement- thickening of the nerve with sensory impairment. Nerve tenderness can also be seen.
  • Detection of acid-fast bacilli in slit-skin smear, skin biopsy, or positive biopsy PCR.

The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of malabsorption syndrome (chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea), a normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy with abnormal schilling test points towards pancreatic insufficiency.

A normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy rules out small intestinal pathologies like celiac disease (option A) and intestinal lymphangiectasia (option C), presence of steatorrhea rules out ulcerative colitis (option B) as it affects the large bowel which is not the main site of absorption of fat.  

Ileal disease is also characterized by normal xylose test, normal duodenal biopsy and steatorrhea and abnormal schilling test but among the given options the most appropriate answer would be pancreatic insufficiency due to chronic pancreatitis.

Pancreatic insufficiency is characterised by the deficiency of exocrine pancreatic enzymes that result in maldigestion and malabsorption.

The features in favor of the diagnosis:

  • Steatorrhea - a deficiency of pancreatic lipases can lead to undigested fat in stools.
  • D-xylose test - d-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing any enzymatic action. Normal d-xylose test denotes intact mucosa.
  • Schilling test - it is abnormal as pancreatic enzymes are required for the absorption of vitamin B12.


Diagnosis of various malabsorption syndromes:

Pathologies D xylose test Duodenal mucosal biopsy Schilling test
Celiac disease Decreased  Abnormal; Short or absent villi; epithelial cell damage; crypts hypertrophy Normal 
Ileal disease Normal  Normal  Abnormal
Chronic pancreatitis Normal  Normal  Abnormal; normal after pancreatic enzymes substitution
Intestinal lymphangiectasia Normal  Abnormal; dilated lymphatics, clubbed villi Normal 
Bacterial overgrowth syndrome Normal or may be abnormal  Usually normal or can have diffuse non specific damage to villi Usually abnormal; normal after antibiotics administration

 

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis shows resistance to which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. 

MDR-TB poses a serious problem in the treatment of TB as isoniazid and rifampicin are the most potent first-line drugs. 

The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the world health organization (WHO).

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid, ethionamide

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. A shorter regimen of 6 months including bedaquiline with other drugs can be used in patients not treated before and without extensive disease. In pregnant women with MRD-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided. 

The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)/ gene Xpert is used to detect rpoB gene polymorphisms, which are responsible for rifampicin resistance. 

The four drugs considered first-line agents in the treatment of TB are isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. 

Isoniazid is an antibiotic that works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, an essential component of the mycobacterial cell wall. It is a bactericidal drug. It acts as a vitamin B6 antagonist, so oral pyridoxine supplementation is recommended during treatment. Side effects include peripheral neuritis, seizures, and ataxia. 

Rifampicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic that inhibits RNA synthesis and is bactericidal. It is also used in the prophylaxis of meningococcal infections. Side effects include rash, vomiting, and hepatitis. It is a microsomal enzyme inducer that can result in contraceptive failure. 

Ethambutol inhibits the mycobacterial cell wall assembly. Side effects include optic neuritis, pruritus, and joint pain.

Pyrazinamide is a nicotinamide analogue activated in acidic conditions. Side effects include liver injury and hyperuricemia.

Other options: Fluoroquinolones are considered second-line agents used in the treatment for drug-resistant TB. Kanamycin, an injectable aminoglycoside is excluded from the new WHO classification of second-line drugs. 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

Continuation phase:

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.

  • Pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most cost-effective method of infection control?
questions.solution:
The most cost-effective method of infection control is hand hygiene.

Infection control refers to the policy and procedures implemented to control and minimize the spread of infections in hospitals and other healthcare settings. It decreases infection rates and the development of multidrug-resistant pathogens. 

The most significant precaution that is effective in preventing infection transmission is hand hygiene. This is achieved by washing hands with soap and water and/or by hand rubbing with alcohol or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizer. The most effective and least expensive way is by washing hands before and after any patient interaction.

Perform hand hygiene

  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • After barehanded touching of instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before and after treating each patient.
  • Before putting on gloves and again immediately after removing gloves.

Use soap and water when hands are visibly soiled (e.g., blood, body fluids); otherwise, an alcohol-based hand rub may be used.

Public health measures and activities such as sanitation, infection control, immunization, and protection of food and water supplies are all basic to primary prevention.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought with complaints of bedwetting at night. There is no history of bedwetting during day time. The findings of urine examination were normal. The specific gravity was 1.020. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the child has nocturnal enuresis with normal findings on urine examination; hence, consulting a child psychologist should be advised.

Nocturnal enuresis: 

At 5 years, volitional control of micturition is expected. When there is an occurrence of involuntary voiding at night after 5 years, it is referred to as nocturnal enuresis.

A careful history should be obtained if the patient presents with involuntary voiding. Fluid intake at night and the pattern of nocturnal enuresis should be evaluated. Children with diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, and chronic renal disease can present with this condition as they have a high obligatory urinary output and compensatory polydipsia.

If physical and urine examinations are normal and no daytime symptoms are seen, then further evaluation for urinary tract pathology is not warranted. An ultrasound is needed in an older child, usually >7 years with enuresis or in those who have not responded to therapy. 

Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age. The initial measure is a psychological therapy that helps the child to deal with enuresis psychologically and motivates the child to void at night if he wakes up with a full bladder. Therapy includes:

  • Motivational therapy (star charts for dry nights),
  • Conditioning therapy (auditory or vibratory alarms),
  • Self-hypnosis.

Pharmacological therapy (imipramine and desmopressin) is intended to treat the symptoms of enuresis and thus is regarded as second-line therapy and is not curative. Desmopressin tablets with a dosage of 0.2-0.6 mg at bedtime can be given.

questions.text: A child was brought to the hospital and was found to have hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and accumulation of highly branched glycogen polymers called limit dextrins. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Cori's disease.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency (glycogen storage disease III) is also known as Cori's disease, Forbes' disease, and limit dextrinosis. The debranching enzyme, together with phosphorylase, is responsible for the complete degradation of glycogen. In this case, the debranching enzyme is defective; hence, the glycogen breakdown is incomplete, which results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains, which resemble limit dextrin.

Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. Muscle weakness is slowly progressive and associated with wasting. Accumulation of limit dextrins is seen in Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency room and was diagnosed with an arrhythmia. The duty doctor tried to manage it by performing a carotid sinus massage. A normal pacemaker potential curve is shown in the image below. Identify the change expected to be seen in this curve after carotid sinus massage.
questions.solution:
The change expected to be seen in this patient after carotid sinus massage is a decrease in the slope of phase 4 of the pacemaker potential curve.

Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver that is used to treat arrhythmias by activating the baroreceptor mechanism. The carotid sinus contains baroreceptors that get activated on physical manipulation. This mechanism, via the nucleus tractus solitarius, sends parasympathetic vagal efferents to the heart.

Phases of pacemaker potential:

  • Phase 0- Upstroke. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3- Downstroke. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channel.

In the clinical scenario, due to vagal stimulation, the parasympathetic cholinergic fibers to the SAN are stimulated. This leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by two mechanisms-

  1. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated→ slowed depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ decreased slope. 
  2. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated → decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)→ decreased firing of T-type Ca2+ channel → decreased slope.

On the other hand, the response to sympathetic stimuli is that of an increased slope of the pacemaker potential. This effect is mediated by two mechanisms-

  1. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → β1 receptor → increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) → rapid opening of L-type Ca2+ channels → increased slope. 
  2. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → increases the depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ increased slope. 

The image given below shows the effect of sympathetic and parasympathetic stimuli on the pacemaker potential:

Related Pearl: Pacemaker potential

questions.text: The given instrument is primarily used for?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Salah's needle used for bone marrow aspiration.

Klima and Salah's needles are reusable bone marrow aspiration needles, both are made of stainless steel. Klima needle has a guard that screws along the length of the needle. It has no side screw. Whereas, Salah's needle has a guard situated 2 cm from the tip and has a side screw. The image below shows Salah's needle.

Option B: Veress Needle is used to produce a pneumoperitoneum in direct puncture laparoscopy. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: The image below shows a cutting-type vim Silverman liver biopsy needle.

Option D: The image below shows a Quincke-type lumbar puncture needle.

questions.text: Which of the following actions of dopamine is not helpful in treating acute shock?

choices.text: Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Alpha-1 agonist action, leading to peripheral vasoconstriction
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.solution:
An increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors is not helpful in case of acute shock.

The systemic effects of dopamine (DA) vary with its concentration in the body. Infusion of low doses of DA activates D1 receptors on renal tubular cells, causing an increase in glomerular filtration rate, renal blood flow, and sodium excretion. This could be used management of low cardiac output associated with compromised renal function, such as severe congestive heart failure, and not acute shock. However, clinical studies argue against the validity of this concept.

At higher concentrations, DA exerts a positive inotropic effect on the myocardium, acting on β1 adrenergic receptors. It also causes the release of norepinephrine from nerve terminals, which contributes to its effects on the heart. It activates vascular α1 receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and increasing systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure. This helps in shock (cardiogenic, vasodilatory), and symptomatic bradycardia unresponsive to atropine or pacing.

Related Pearl: Dose dependent action of dopamine

Dose Infusion rate
mcg/kg/min 		 Effects
Low <2 D1 and D2 stimulation(D1>D2): Increase in renal blood flow and urine output
Medium 2-5 β1 stimulation: Additional cardiac stimulation
High 5-15 α1 stimulation: Vasoconstriction and increase in blood pressure

questions.text: The image given below shows the right humerus. All of the following muscles are inserted at the point marked "X," except _______.
questions.solution:
The bony prominence marked X in the image is the greater tubercle. Subscapularis is not attached to the greater tubercle of the humerus.

Rotator cuff muscles:

The rotator cuff is a group of 4 muscles (SITS) that stabilizes the shoulder joint:

Muscle Insertion Innervation
S: Supraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve
I: Infraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve 
T: Teres Minor Greater tubercle Axillary nerve

The following image shows the bony prominences on the proximal part of the humerus:

 

The following image shows the muscles around the shoulder:

 

Clinical correlation: 

Shoulder impingement syndrome, also called subacromial impingement, painful arc syndrome, supraspinatus syndrome, or swimmer's shoulder, is a clinical syndrome that occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space.

questions.text: Data about recent trends of immunization of children in the community can be found by:
questions.solution:
Data about recent trends of immunization in the community can be found in district surveys.

The RCH program conducts district-based rapid household surveys to assess the reproductive health status of women. It includes

  • Percentage of pregnant women with full ANC
  • Percentage of institutional deliveries and home deliveries
  • Percentage of home deliveries by the trained birth attendant
  • The current contraceptive prevalence rate
  • Percentage of children fully immunized
  • Percentage of unmet needs for family planning
  • Percentage of household reported visits by a health worker in previous 3 months.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a harmonic scalpel. It is an instrument that uses ultrasonic energy to cut tissues while simultaneously coagulating them.

The scalpel vibrates in the 20000–50000 Hz range and cuts through tissues, achieving hemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation using vibration rather than heat.

The different modes of electrosurgery are as follows:

  • Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low-voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.
  • Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.
  • A blend is a combination of cutting and coagulation.
  • Fulguration refers to the destructive coagulation of tissues with charring. The diathermy matching is set to coagulation and a higher effective voltage is used to make larger sparks jump an air gap thus fulgurating the tissues.

The bipolar cautery contains two tips, unlike unipolar cautery, which has only one tip. The current flows between these two tips, and hence, it does not need a return electrode, unlike the unipolar cautery.

LigaSure vessel sealing system (shown below) is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength.

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: Administering epinephrine to a person on which of the following drugs will lead to the vasomotor reversal of Dale?
questions.solution:
The vasomotor reversal of Dale seen on administering epinephrine is seen when an alpha blocker like phentolamine has been previously administered.

Rapid IV injection of adrenaline produces a marked increase in both systolic as well as diastolic BP because at high concentrations, α response predominates and vasoconstriction occurs. As the concentration declines, adrenaline is not able to act on α receptors but continues to act on β2 receptors.

When an α blocker has been given and then adrenaline is injected, only a fall in BP instead of an initial rise is seen, an effect first described by Dale and hence called vasomotor reversal of Dale. This is due to adrenaline's action only on β2 receptors, which are not blocked by phentolamine.

Among the given options, only phentolamine is an α blocker, which abolishes the pressor effect of the epinephrine and produces vasodilation, leading to a vasomotor reversal of Dale.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mmHg was noted. His SpO2 became 90%, his blood pressure dropped to 80/50 mmHg, and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?
  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation

EtCO2- End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
A sudden fall in EtCO2 with hypotension (fall in BP to 80/50 mmHg) along with normal airway pressure (< 35 to 40 cm of H2O) during surgery is suggestive of CO2 embolism.

Intraoperative pulmonary embolism usually presents as sudden cardiovascular collapse and hypoxemia with a sudden fall in EtCO2. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus. If air is identified in the right atrium, or if it is suspected, immediate central vein cannulation and aspiration of the air may be lifesaving.

The placement of a vena cava filter should be considered postoperatively.

The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.

Other options:

Intraoperative bronchospasm is usually manifested as wheezing, increasing peak airway pressure, and a slowly rising waveform on the capnograph.

A pneumothorax may manifest as hypercapnia along with hypoxemia, hypotension, increased peak airway pressure, and decreasing tidal volumes. It may result in abrupt cardiovascular collapse unresponsive to fluid and vasopressor administration.

Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph points towards pneumothorax. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.
The below chest X-ray shows left pneumothorax. Notice the collapsed lung and absent lung markings on the left side. Also mediastinal shift towards the right side.

Endobronchial intubation shows increased peak expiratory pressure, hypoxemia, increased airway pressure, asymmetric chest expansion and the absence of breath sounds over one lung, generally the left. 

Note: Peak airway pressure is the amount of airway pressure delivered by the ventilator to overcome the resistance of the endotracheal tube, airway, and alveoli.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Meckel’s diverticulum?

choices.text: It is located within 2 inches from the ileocecal valve
It has 3 types of heterotopic mucosa
It is approximately 2 feet in length

questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum containing all layers of the intestine. Diverticula that contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. Others are false diverticula.

Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)(option B)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve (option A)
    • approximately 2 inches in length (option D)
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleeds in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text:
Presence of which of the following hepatitis B serologic markers would be consistent with HBV/HDV superinfection?

1. HBsAg
2. Anti HBsAg IgM
3. Anti HBcAg IgG
4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
HDV superinfection occurs when a person who is already chronically infected with HBV acquires HDV. Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with the presence of HBs Ag, Anti HBc Ag, and HBV DNA. 

The infection of HDV on chronic hepatitis B can accelerate the progression to severe disease in all ages. HDV superinfection accelerates progression to cirrhosis almost a decade earlier than HBV mono-infected persons. 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is the first marker to appear in the serum and it indicates the presence of infection. If it is persistent for more than 6 months, it is suggestive of chronic infection. 

Anti-HBs are the antibodies to HBs and are seen after clearance of HBsAg or post-vaccination. Thus, it is suggestive of recovery, non-infectivity and immunity.

Anti-HBc (antibodies to hepatitis B core antigen) has IgM and IgG. IgM anti-HBc is diagnostic of acute hepatitis and it appears soon after HBs Ag. It persists for 3-6 months and can re-appear in flare-ups. IgG anti-HBc appears during acute infection and persists indefinitely irrespective of the recovery or progression to chronic disease.

HBV DNA is a sensitive indicator for viral replication and infectivity. HBeAg also indicates viral replication and infectivity. It appears shortly after HBs Ag and if it is persisting beyond 3 months, it is suggestive of chronic hepatitis. 

Hepatitis B virus is mainly transmitted by percutaneous route followed by perinatal and sexual transmission. Chronic hepatitis B is a progression of acute hepatitis. Chronic hepatitis B infection has five phases - immune tolerant phase, immune active phase, inactive HBsAg carrier state, reactivated chronic hepatitis B phase, and HBsAg negative phase.

Treatment options include interferon, lamivudine, adefovir, entecavir, telbivudine, and tenofovir.

Prophylaxis is by hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and recombinant vaccine. 

HDV superinfection occurs when a person who is already chronically infected with HBV acquires HDV. The infection of HDV on chronic hepatitis B can accelerate the progression to severe disease in all ages. HDV superinfection accelerates progression to cirrhosis almost a decade earlier than HBV mono-infected persons. 

HBV/HDV coinfection occurs when a person simultaneously becomes infected with both HBV and HDV. In acute hepatitis, simultaneous infection with HBV and HDV can lead to mild-to-severe hepatitis. The signs and symptoms typically appear 3–7 weeks after the initial infection and include fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, dark urine, pale stools, jaundice (yellow eyes), and even fulminant hepatitis. However, recovery is usually complete.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with multiple episodes of bleeding per rectum. Colonoscopy revealed more than 100 polyps, and the histopathologic image of the polyp is shown below. Genetic studies reveal STK11 mutation. Her father died of pancreatic cancer a few years back. The presenting feature of this condition may include all of the following, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and histopathological image are suggestive of  Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. It is not associated with pigmented ocular fundus. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) presents with pigmented ocular fundus and is usually associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter. Female patients are encouraged to attend breast and cervical screening.

Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp. If surgery is done for these indications, attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

Related Pearl: Polyposis Syndromes

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with frequent nosebleeds is brought to the OPD for a routine check-up.  He has a history of excessive bleeding during a dental procedure that he underwent recently.  Which factor responsible for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall is defective?
questions.solution:
The factor responsible for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall that is defective in this child is von Willebrand factor (vWF).

Platelet adhesion is mediated by interactions between the platelet surface receptor glycoprotein Ib -GpIb and vWF in the subendothelial matrix. Endothelial injury exposes vWF and causes the adhesion of platelets by the GpIb receptor. ADP binding to ADP receptors (Option B) induces conformational changes in platelets. This change in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (Option C) that occurs with platelet activation allows it to bind to fibrinogen, which leads to aggregation of platelets to each other and not to the endothelium.

The defect in vWF causes von Willebrand disease. The most common presenting symptoms are spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia with a normal platelet count.

Factor VIII is found bound to the von Willebrand factor (vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolonged aPTT in this disease (Option A). Prolonged bleeding time is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation

questions.text: According to the malaria treatment guidelines, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women
Presumptive treatment with chloroquine should be given
Primaquine is to be given for 7 days in falciparum malaria
ACT should not be given in falciparum malaria

questions.solution:
According to guidelines, primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women.

To prevent relapse from Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale malaria in children and adults a 14-day course of primaquine is given in all transmission settings. It is not used in pregnant women, infants aged < 6 months, women breastfeeding infants aged < 6 months, and people with G6PD deficiency.

Artemisinin combination therapy (ACT) (Artesunate 3 days + sulphadoxine-purimethamine 1 day) should be given to all confirmed P. falciparum cases along with single dose of primaquine on Day 2.

According to the revised drug policy 2013, there is no scope of presumptive treatment in malaria control in India.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, her height is normal and the breast development is appropriate for her age. However, the axillary and pubic hair is sparse. On ultrasound, an absent uterus is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has primary amenorrhea, and the most likely diagnosis is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. They appear as phenotypically normal females at birth and often present with primary amenorrhea at puberty. External genitalia will appear normal with scant or absent pubic and axillary hair, shortened vagina. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. However, they develop breasts during pubertal maturation due to abundant androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Testes may be palpable in the labia or inguinal area or in the abdomen.

There are two causes of primary amenorrhea with the absent uterus and the differences between them are as follows:

Presentation Mullerian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattern Sporadic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomaly Yes  No

Other options:

Option B: Mullerian agenesis would have normal pubic and axillary hair but absent or rudimentary uterus.

Option C: Turner's syndrome is associated with the presence of a uterus, short stature and raised FSH levels.

Option D: Amenorrhea due to hypothalamic failure may be due to eating disorders, excessive exercise, or stress. It can also be inherited like 

Kallmann syndrome. The uterus is normal with decreased FSH and LH levels.

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days, with the following rash on his trunk and legs. His BP is 70/50 mmHg and neck stiffness is present. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF with 4200 cells/μL, a protein level of 198 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following correctly describes the organisms causing this condition?

choices.text: Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidize glucose and maltose
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidase negative, catalase negative
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidize lactose and sucrose

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing petechial rashes are suggestive of fulminant meningococcemia. This condition is caused by Neisseria meningitidis/meningococci- gram-negative diplococci that oxidize glucose and maltose.

Neisseria meningitidis is an aerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile diplococcus. They are catalase and oxidase positive. Glucose and maltose are oxidized, but lactose and sucrose are not oxidized.

The cocci spread from the nasopharynx to the meninges by traveling along the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve with an initial flu-like infection.  Meningococcemia presents as an acute onset fever with chills, malaise with a petechial rash in early disease. The patient develops signs of meningitis, such as intense headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck. It may progress to a coma within a few hours.

Fulminant meningococcemia is more severe, presenting with a high fever and a hemorrhagic rash; the patient may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation and ultimate circulatory collapse with bilateral hemorrhagic necrosis of the adrenal glands with subsequent adrenal failure, also known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic with a complaint of multiple episodes of loose watery stool for 3 days.  Which of the following is the most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults is Norovirus.

Norovirus is the most common agent to cause viral gastroenteritis among older children and adults. Noroviruses previously called Norwalk-like viruses belong to the family Caliciviridae.

Gastroenteritis caused by Norovirus has a sudden onset and generally lasts 1-3 days. It is characterized by nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhoea and constitutional symptoms like headache, fever, chills, and myalgias. Vomiting is more prevalent among children, whereas a greater proportion of adults develop diarrhoea. The stools are characteristically loose and watery, without blood, mucus, or leukocytes.

Other options:

Option A- Enteric adenoviruses cause diarrheal episodes in young children which consists of ~2–12% of all diarrheal episodes in children.

Option B- Rotavirus is the most common viral agent among young children. Nearly all children are infected with rotavirus by 3–5 years of age. Infants and young children who develop severe dehydration are more likely to have an infection from rotavirus than other viruses.

Option D- Cytomegalovirus causes mononucleosis in healthy individuals and disseminated diseases like leukopenia, hepatitis, colitis, pneumonitis, esophagitis, gastritis, and retinitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 4-month history of cough with hemoptysis, diarrhea, and flushing episodes. Biopsy of a mass showed atypical cells with microscopic necrosis and 5 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields. Chromogranin staining was positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid which is an atypical carcinoid.

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that are subclassified into typical and atypical carcinoids. Typical carcinoids have <2 mitoses per 10 high-power fields (HPF) and lack necrosis; atypical carcinoids have 2-10 mitoses per 10 high-power fields and/or foci of necrosis. Atypical carcinoids also show increased pleomorphism, have more prominent nucleoli, and are more likely to grow in a disorganized fashion and invade lymphatics.

They present as persistent cough, hemoptysis, secondary infections, bronchiectasis, and atelectasis caused by the intraluminal growth of these lesions. They cause carcinoid syndrome, characterized by intermittent attacks of diarrhea, flushing, bronchospasm, and cyanosis. 5-hydroxy-indole-acetic acid and chromogranin A are markers used to diagnose carcinoid tumors. 

Histologically, it is composed of trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit dense-core neurosecretory granules. Immunohistochemistry is positive for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, and calcitonin.

Other options:

Option B: Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. They are also positive for chromogranin but they do not present with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome.

Option C: Large cell carcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor that lacks the cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer. The cells typically have large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate amount of cytoplasm. It is a diagnosis of exclusion since it expresses none of the markers associated with adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic for the flu vaccine and you recommend the trivalent influenza vaccine. This vaccine contains all the following strains, except ____.
questions.solution:
The influenza vaccine does not contain the H2N1 strain.

The trivalent and quadrivalent influenza vaccines are intended to protect against 3 and 4 flu viruses, respectively: influenza A viruses, H1N1 and H3N2, and one or two influenza B viruses.

They can either be a killed vaccine or live attenuated vaccines.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tramadol apart from acting on opioid receptors?
questions.solution:
Tramadol also acts by serotonin (5HT) and norepinephrine (NE) reuptake inhibition.

Tramadol is a synthetic analog of codeine, which is a weak mu-opioid receptor agonist. Part of its analgesic effect is produced by the inhibition of the uptake of NE and 5HT. It is only effective in the treatment of mild to moderate pain and not severe or chronic pain. 

It produces less respiratory depression and less constipation. It is epileptogenic and can cause seizures in predisposed individuals. Tramadol should not be used in patients taking monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors, SSRIs, or other drugs that lower the seizure threshold. 

It causes serotonin syndrome in combination with SSRIs and atypical antipsychotics due to monoamine uptake inhibition.

questions.text: A patient in the postoperative ward was under opioid medication for pain relief. His respiratory rate was 7 cycles/min. Which of the following acid-base abnormality will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of decreased respiratory rate in a patient receiving opioids is suggestive of opioid overdose. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Opioid overdose causes respiratory depression and hypoventilation. Hypoventilation results in the accumulation of carbon dioxide, thereby increasing PaCO2 levels (hypercapnia). The increase in PaCO2, in turn, decreases the bicarbonate (HCO3–)/PaCO2 ratio, thereby decreasing the pH. This is called respiratory acidosis (low pH, high PaCO2).

Physiological compensation takes place to bring the pH back to normal. In acute respiratory acidosis, the body’s compensation occurs in 2 steps. The initial response is cellular buffering that takes place over minutes to hours. Cellular buffering causes a slight elevation in plasma bicarbonate values. The second step is renal compensation that occurs over 3-5 days. With renal compensation, renal excretion of carbonic acid is increased, and bicarbonate reabsorption is increased.

Respiratory changes (changes in PCO2) promote a corresponding change in metabolic response (changes in HCO3-) and vice versa as a compensatory mechanism. In general, PCO2 and HCO3- move in the same direction for compensation in metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders, respectively. A change in the two parameters in opposite directions points to a mixed acid-base disturbance.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: In a suspected patient of dengue, all of these are acceptable investigations on day 3 of presentation, except _______.

choices.text: ELISA for antibody against dengue virus
Viral culture and isolation in C6/36 cell line

questions.solution:
All the above investigations are acceptable at day 3 of presentation, except ELISA for antibody against dengue virus.

Dengue viruses belong to flaviviruses that cause fever and myalgia syndrome. It presents with sudden onset of fever, frontal headache, retro-orbital pain, back pain, and severe myalgias.

During the early stages of the disease- before day 5 of illness during the febrile period, diagnosis can be made by virus isolation in cell culture, by detection of viral RNA by RT-PCR, or by detection of viral antigens by ELISA or rapid tests.

  • Virus isolation can be done during the period of viremia i.e. usually before day 5. The mosquito cell line C6/36 or AP61 are the host cells of choice for routine isolation of the dengue virus.  
  • RT-PCR - rapid turnaround time.
  • NS1 antigen can be detected up to 7-10 days after the onset of illness.

After day 5, dengue viruses and antigens disappear from the blood with the appearance of specific antibodies. The presence of IgM antibody or raising titres of IgG antibody on ELISA is used for the detection and distinguishing primary and secondary dengue infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with claudication in the right lower limb. Arterial doppler reveals a narrowing of the popliteal artery. The diameter was found to be reduced to one-third. How much will the blood flow reduce by?
questions.solution:
The blood flow through the vessel decreases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the diameter is reduced to 1/3rd, implying the radius is also reduced to 1/3rd. Therefore, the flow decreases by (1/3) 4 = 1/81

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck, and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve.
The right side nerve is shorter than the left.
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.
It is purely a motor nerve.

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the right phrenic nerve, and it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

 It is derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami. It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.

At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is seperated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

Right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left.

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the central parts of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 33-year-old fitness enthusiast comes to the clinic with lethargy, muscle pains, and anorexia. On examination, he has dermatitis around the eyes, nose, and mouth. Further evaluation reveals a deficiency of the vitamin that functions as a cofactor in the reaction below. This vitamin is not required for which of these other reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes the symptom complex of a patient with biotin deficiency. The conversion of oxaloacetate to malate (option d) is catalyzed by the enzyme malate dehydrogenase. This reaction does not require biotin as a cofactor.

Biotin serves as an important cofactor in carboxylation reactions, where biotin functions as a carrier for the activated carbon dioxide molecule.

Biotin deficiency is commonly seen in patients who consume large quantities of egg whites (as is possible in this patient who is a fitness enthusiast) which contains avidin, a substance that binds to biotin and prevents its absorption.

Biotin-dependent carboxylation:

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase- involved in the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase- It catalyzes the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an ATP-requiring reaction in which the vitamin biotin is the coenzyme.
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase- propionyl-CoA is carboxylated to d-methyl malonyl-CoA, which is catalyzed by propionyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase - involved in the carboxylation of β-methylcrotonyl CoA to β-methylglutaconyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is not preferred in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which is contraindicated in pregnancy.

The following drugs are used as antihypertensives in pregnancy:

  1. Labetalol: Given orally 100 mg TID; can be given IV in hypertensive crisis; side effects include tremors, headache, asthma, and congestive cardiac failure.
  2. Methyldopa: Given orally 250 mg BID; may be increased to 1 g QID depending upon the response. Adverse effects include postural hypotension, hemolytic anemia, sodium retention, and excessive sedation in mothers. 
  3. Nifedipine: 5–10 mg TID can be given. Side effects include flushing, hypotension, headache, tachycardia, and inhibition of labor.
  4. Hydralazine: 100 mg/day in four divided doses can be given. Adverse effects include maternal hypotension, tachycardia, arrhythmia, palpitation, lupus-like syndrome, and fluid retention.

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. They should be avoided during pregnancy. Suitable for chronic hypertension in a nonpregnant state or postpartum. When ACE inhibitors are given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause fetal hypotension, renal hypoperfusion, and renal ischemia.
