questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a patient to evaluate the patency of fallopian tubes, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube, which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis: The leading presenting complaints include infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well.

Investigation:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography- If genital tuberculosis is suspected, it should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette-type of appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular-like outpouchings surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

3. Endometrial histology and PCR testing: Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The late premenstrual phase is the ideal time to schedule this procedure. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. PCR is a rapid, sensitive, and specific method of detecting mycobacterial DNA.

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

The image below shows the "pipe stem" or "lead pipe" appearance. There is an absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe-like appearance shows the fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

The image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

All the other options - N. gonorrhea, C. trachomatis, and Mycoplasma hominis are causative agents for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Acute PID presents with abdominal pain and tenderness where sonography is a primary imaging tool. Normal fallopian tubes are rarely imaged. Characteristic acute findings include: a distended, ovoid-shaped tube filled with anechoic or echogenic fluid, fallopian tube wall thickening, incomplete internal septa, and a "cogwheel" appearance when inflamed tubes are imaged in cross-section.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods can be used to precipitate proteins?
  1. Adding trichloroacetic acid
  2. Moving pH away from isoelectric pH
  3. Using heavy metal ions
  4. Adding alcohol
questions.solution:
Methods that can be used to precipitate proteins: Adding trichloroacetic acid, using heavy metal ions, and adding alcohol. Hence, option C is correct.

Precipitation of proteins is maximum at isoelectric pH and decreases as pH moves away from it. Hence, moving pH away from isoelectric pH is not an effective method to precipitate proteins.

The isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI) is the pH at which the molecule carries no net charge.

Significance of iso-electric pH (pI):

  • The number of anions and cations present on the protein molecule will be equal and the net charge is zero.
  • The proteins will not migrate in an electrical field
  • Buffering capacity is minimum
  • Viscosity will be minimum
  • Precipitability will be maximum, and solubility is minimum.

Various precipitation reactions of proteins:

  1. Salting out: higher the molecular weight of protein, the lesser the salt required. Globulins would require only half-saturated salt whereas albumin would need full saturation. 
  2. Isoelectric precipitation: proteins are least soluble at their isoelectric pH and get precipitated immediately.
  3. Precipitation by organic solvents like alcohol and acetone.
  4. Precipitation by heavy metal ions: positively charged metal ions precipitate the negatively charged proteins in an alkaline medium. Salts of heavy metals can precipitate normal proteins of the GI tract in poisoning.
  5. Precipitation by alkaloidal reagents like tungstic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and picric acid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was brought to the emergency room in a semi-conscious state after falling from his bike. He was intubated by the paramedics on the way to the emergency room. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli, and on observation of his posture, he is seen to have a decorticate posture. What would his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score be?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score based on the given clinical scenario is E2 VNT M3.

It is calculated as follows:

  • E: Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • V: Intubated. Thus, not testable - NT
  • M: Decorticate posturing - 3

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain.
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in GCS.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons.
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the GCS.

The below image shows decerebrate and decorticate posturing.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient presents with generalized rash, cough, and breathlessness. Peripheral smear reveals eosinophilia. To diagnose hypereosinophilic syndrome, what should be the absolute eosinophil count?
questions.solution:
Patients with an absolute eosinophil count of >1.5 x 109/L or >1500/mm3 are diagnosed with hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES).

HES is defined by the association of HE, with eosinophil-mediated organ damage and/or dysfunction, provided other potential causes for the damage have been excluded.

It is a rare syndrome in which patients present with rashes, cough, and breathlessness and may also have gastrointestinal and neurological manifestations.

Evaluation involves assessing end-organ damage with laboratory tests for liver enzymes, creatine kinase, renal function, and troponin and ECG, echocardiography, PFT, etc. It is also important to complete bone marrow histology and cytogenetic studies.

Corticosteroids are the mainstay to treat HES.

Differential diagnosis of eosinophilia:

  • Bronchial asthma
  • Loffler syndrome
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome
  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following drugs come under Schedule H of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1945?

choices.text: Biologicals and special products like insulin, toxin and antitoxins
Drugs  purchased with the prescription of a qualified doctor
Drugs with a warning label  “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision”

questions.solution:
Schedule H includes drugs purchased over the counter with the prescription of a qualified doctor.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, classify drugs under different schedules based on their potential for abuse, their therapeutic value, and other factors. The rules provide guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Other options:

Option A- Biological and special products like insulin, toxin, and antitoxins are included under Schedule C.

Option B- Bacterial vaccines are included under Schedule F I.

Option D- Drugs that should be labelled with the words “Caution: it is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision” are included under Schedule G.

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule Details
Schedule C Biological and other special products e.g. Toxins, Insulin, Sera & Antibiotics.
Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.
Schedule F

Blood and blood products

F I - Production of Bacterial vaccines, Anti- Sera

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation
Schedule G With a label of Caution, dangerous to use except under medical supervision.
Schedule H Prescription drugs.
Schedule J List of diseases that a drug may not prevent or cure. Eg - HIV & Atherosclerosis
Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices
Schedule P Regulations regarding the life period and storage of various drugs.
Schedule W Drugs marketed under generic names.
Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.
Schedule Y Requirement and guidelines for import/ manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: Identify the true statement about this procedure.

choices.text: B can be performed without intrathecal contrast, while A cannot
B is invasive, while A is non-invasive
Severe claustrophobia is not a contraindication to B, but it is for A
B can dynamically evaluate active CSF leaks, while A cannot

questions.solution:
The procedures depicted in images A and B represent X-ray myelography and MR myelography, respectively. MR myelography (B) can be performed without intrathecal contrast, while X-ray myelography (A) requires contrast.

X-ray myelography can be used to dynamically evaluate the spinal canal in patients with spondylolisthesis, arachnoiditis, active CSF leaks, and in the assessment of the spine post-operatively. Myelography is also done when there is a contraindication to MR such as a non-compatible pacemaker and severe claustrophobia.

Myelographic MR images are obtained without the injection of intrathecal contrast. It is a non-invasive, painless procedure and precludes exposure to radiation.

MR imaging has almost completely replaced X-ray myelography; however, the advantages of X-ray myelography over MR imaging are as follows:

  • Lower signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of MR myelography (B) compared to X-ray myelography (A) can result in missing small lesions on myelographic MR (B) images.
  • Allows dynamic and functional evaluation of the CSF and helps in the evaluation of active CSF leaks.
  • Myelography is useful in the evaluation of a postoperative spine. Artefacts of surgical material may obscure the spinal canal or nerve roots on MRI.

questions.text: A patient presents with tinnitus and hearing loss. CT of the brain showed a tumor at the cerebellopontine angle. An image from the biopsy is shown below. What does the area marked with an arrow represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Verocay bodies, which are found in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that often arise from cranial and peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They can be sporadic or associated with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF1) or occur as vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) in cases of neurofibromatosis-2 (NF2).

They present with features of nerve compression involving both the adjacent structures and the nerve involved. Most tumors occur in the cranium as acoustic neuromas that affect vestibular branch of VIII cranial nerve near the cerebellopontine angle. They present with tinnitus, hearing loss, and symptoms resulting from compression of the brainstem and cerebellum.

Microscopically, they are comprised of a mixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. 

  • Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern
  • The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.
  • Antoni A area leaves central nuclear-free zones surrounded by the palisading of nuclei, resulting in the formation of structures termed Verocay bodies.


Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. They are seen in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with myopia at 10 years of age came for an opinion on LASIK surgery. On routine preoperative assessment, the estimated residual stromal bed was calculated to be 200 μm, and surgery was deferred. Which of the following anticipated complications made the surgeon take such a decision?
questions.solution:
LASIK, when performed in this patient, would predispose him to ectasia of the cornea (keratectasia) because of the inadequate residual stromal bed thickness.

Because LASIK is a procedure involving the ablation of stroma, a preoperative calculation of the residual stromal bed thickness can aid the eye surgeon to predict the postoperative risk for corneal ectasia.

The residual stromal bed thickness can be calculated by subtracting the anticipated flap thickness and maximum ablation depth from the central corneal thickness. A residual stromal bed thickness of 250 to 300 μm is generally recognized as a minimum requirement before LASIK surgery. Hence, the calculation of central corneal thickness is an important element of preoperative evaluation.

Patient selection is of utmost importance in refractive eye surgeries. The following factors must be considered before taking up a patient for refractive eye surgery.

  • Minimum age of 21 years
  • Stable refraction for at least 1 year
  • Measurement of the central corneal thickness ( to calculate the residual stromal bed thickness)
  • A detailed review of ocular and systemic conditions

Limitations and contraindications of LASIK: The following group of patients poses a high risk for laser vision correction, and when done are associated with adverse surgical outcomes.

  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases
  • Pregnant and nursing mothers
  • Keratoconus
  • Chronic intake of isotretinoin and amiodarone
  • Fuchs corneal dystrophy
  • Ophthalmic herpes simplex and herpes zoster

Other options:

Option A- Punctate epithelial dystrophy (dry eye) is the most frequent complication of LASIK surgery, and the same can be managed with frequent lubrication using artificial tears.

Option B- Flap displacement usually occurs within 24 hours after surgery. Once diagnosed, the flap should be lifted and repositioned as soon as possible.

Option D- The corneal epithelium grows in the interface between the flap and stromal bed. This is termed epithelial ingrowth. If it causes vision disturbances, Nd:YAG laser application is warranted to treat the condition.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: Which of the following situations is associated with a high failure in the interpretation of the following test in a population?
questions.solution:
The above image is of tuberculin test. There is a high failure in the interpretation of the test if a high percentage of people are immunized.

The interpretation of tuberculin tests has become complicated in countries with high coverage of BCG vaccination at birth since most of the vaccines become positive reactors to the tuberculin tests. This presents a problem in identifying the true prevalence of infection. Cross-sensitivity to atypical mycobacteria has also caused the prevalence to be over-estimated.

The test can be negative in cases of immune suppression like malignancy, Hodgkin's disease, HIV infection, malnutrition, severe bacterial infection, immunosuppressive drugs, etc. A population with a high HIV caseload may have a falsely low prevalence of the test. 

Related Pearl: Tuberculin reaction size & candidates for treatment of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

Risk Group Positive Tuberculin Reaction Size
HIV infected persons ≥5 mm
Recent contacts of a patient with TB ≥5 mm
Organ transplant recipients ≥5 mm
Persons with fibrotic lesions consistent with old TB on chest radiography ≥5 mm
Immunosuppressed persons ≥5 mm
Persons with high risk medical conditions (silicosis & end stage renal disease) ≥5 mm
Injection drug users ≥10 mm
Mycobacteriology lab personnel ≥10 mm
Children <5 years of age ≥10 mm
Recent immigrants from high prevalence countries

≥10 mm
Low-risk persons

           ≥15 mm

 

Tuberculin reactions are read at 48-72 hr as the transverse diameter of the induration, and the diameter of the erythema is NOT considered.

questions.text: Which of these is the best study to evaluate intervention and outcome?
questions.solution:
The best study to evaluate the intervention and outcome is a randomized controlled trial (RCT).

RCTs are concerned with evaluating therapeutic agents, mainly drugs with respect to their effect and outcome. It is a type of experimental study. They involve some intervention or manipulation like the application or withdrawal of the suspected cause or changing one variable in the causative chain in the experimental group while making no change in the control group, and observing and comparing the outcome of the experiment in both groups.

Cohort studies and case-control studies are good at showing an association between a cause or suspected risk factor and subsequent disease (or effect). Relative risk (RR) calculated in cohort studies and Odds Ratio (OR) in case-control studies measure the strength of the association between risk factors and outcomes.

A cross-sectional study is a prevalence study that is more useful for the study of chronic diseases. It is more appropriate for the study of the distribution of a disease in a population than for studying its etiology.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describing decrease in movement of right leg (neurological symptom) in a young female with history of episodic attacks of abdominal pain and aggressive behaviour (mental symptom) is consistent with the diagnosis of acute intermittent prophyria.

Conversion disorder (Option D) presents commonly in young women as acute, temporary loss of sensory or motor function preceded by psychological issues. Recurrent episodic attacks of neurovisceral symptoms make the diagnosis of conversion disorder unlikely.

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a hepatic porphyria inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase/hydroxymethylbilane synthase/uroporphyrinogen I synthase enzyme in heme synthesis. AIP is generally latent before puberty and is more common in women. 

AIP presents with neurovisceral symptoms and no cutaneous manifestations are seen. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom. Nausea, vomiting, constipation, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are seen. Tachycardia, hypertension, restlessness, tremors, and excess sweating are due to sympathetic overactivity. Peripheral neuropathy predominantly affecting motor neurons is due to axonal degeneration. During acute episodes, individuals may experience mental manifestations such as anxiety, insomnia, depression, hallucinations, and paranoia. Seizures may result from either neurological effects or hyponatremia.

Diagnosis can be made with the appearance of classic symptomology after exposure to an underlying precipitating factor. Plasma and urine ALA and PBG levels are significantly raised during an acute attack and remain high even after symptoms resolve.

Intravenous hematin as first-line treatment for acute attacks. Narcotic analgesia may be given for abdominal pain. Carbohydrate loading with intravenous glucose may be tried in milder attacks. Orthoptic liver transplant is curative in patients refractory to hemin therapy.

Givosiran is a recently approved hepatic-targeted RNA interference (RNAi) therapy for acute hepatic porphyrias.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presented with the finding shown below. He gives a history of chronic smoking. His CT angiography shows a block of the popliteal vessel with distal collateral formation. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking is the best measure to stop progression of disease
Vasodilators can improve circulation of the affected limb
Nerves and veins of the corresponding segment can  be affected
Skip lesions are characteristic of ischemia to the limb

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing gangrene of the first three toes point toward the diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). Vasodilators have no role in improving circulation in the affected limb in this condition.

Buerger’s disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.

Clinical features:

  • Typically presents in young male smokers, with symptoms beginning prior to age 40.
  • Patients initially present with foot, leg, arm, or hand claudication which may progress to rest pain to calf claudication and eventually ischemic rest pain and ulcerations on the toes, feet, or fingers and even gangrene.
  • A complete history should exclude diabetes, hyperlipidemia, or autoimmune disease as possible etiologies for the occlusive lesions.

Pathogenesis:

Smoking increases the level of carboxyhemoglobin which causes vasospasm and hyperplasia of the intima of small and medium-sized vessels. This eventually results in thrombosis and obliteration of vessels followed by segmental panarteritis. Eventually, artery, vein, and nerve are together involved which causes rest pain (nerve involvement), and ischemia in the limb (arterial involvement).

Once blockage occurs, plenty of collaterals open up depending on the site of blockage to maintain blood supply to the ischaemic area resulting in a  Compensatory peripheral vascular disease. If the patient continues to smoke, the disease progresses into the collaterals, blocking them eventually, leading to severe ischemia and is called decompensatory peripheral vascular disease.

It is presently called critical limb ischemia. It causes rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (Doppler + B mode U/S)
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique
  • Characteristic angiographic findings show disease confinement to the distal circulation, usually infrapopliteal and distal to the brachial artery. The occlusions are segmental and show “skip” lesions with extensive collateralization, the so-called corkscrew collaterals.


Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.

questions.text: A baby boy at 7 months of age presented with a history of vomiting and failure to thrive. On evaluation, he is found to have raised blood ammonia levels and no ketones. Also, he has high plasma glutamine and alanine levels, with low levels of citrulline and arginine. Which is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby is ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC). 

In this X-linked disorder, males are more severely affected than females. In this disorder, there are episodes of hyperammonemia which is manifested by vomiting, and neurologic abnormalities like ataxia, mental confusion, agitation, combativeness, and frank psychosis. These episodes are separated by the period of wellness.

Laboratory findings during the acute attack:

  • Hyperammonemia is accompanied by marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine. High glutamine in urine is usually seen in hyperammonemia as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.
  • The blood level of urea is low.
  • A marked increase in the urinary excretion of orotic acid. Orotate precipitates in urine as pink-colored gravel or stones.
  • Increased uracil in urine is also seen. When OTC is deficient carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria spills into the cytoplasm then it enters into pyrimidine synthesis. 

 The diagnosis is most conveniently confirmed by gene analysis.

Other options:

Option A: In the near-complete enzymatic deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1, symptoms appear during the 1st few days or even hours of life. the baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsion, coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. Orotic aciduria and increased production of pyrimidines like uracil in this case are not seen in Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency.

Option C: Arginase deficiency is a rare distal urea cycle disorder that presents as acute neonatal form with intractable seizures, cerebral edema, and death. Laboratory findings include marked elevations of arginine in plasma and CSF.

Option D: The deficiency of the Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, also called classic citrullinemia.  The severe or neonatal form (the most common form) appears in the 1st few days of life with signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia. In the subacute or mild form, clinical findings such as failure to thrive, frequent vomiting, developmental delay, and dry, brittle hair appear gradually after 1 year of age. Laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with OTC deficiency, except that the plasma citrulline concentration is greatly elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of St. Anthony’s fire?
questions.solution:
Dry gangrene, and not wet gangrene, is a feature of St. Anthony's fire.  

St. Anthony's fire is another name for ergotism. Ergot alkaloids exert their primary CNS effects by stimulating adrenergic receptors, both centrally and peripherally.  

Clinical features

  • Acute poisoning:
    • GI - Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
    • CNS effects - Headache, giddiness
    • Respiratory - Chest tightness, difficulty in breathing
    • Musculoskeletal - Weakness, exhaustion, tingling, numbness, paresthesia 
  • Chronic poisoning:
    • Tingling and numbness
    • Dry gangrene due to vasomotor disturbance
    • Tactile hallucination - Formication

questions.text:
The correct sequence of maturation of sperms in spermatogenesis:
  1. Spermatozoa
  2. Spermatogonia
  3. Spermatocytes
  4. Spermatid
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is Spermatogonia -> Spermatocytes -> Spermatid -> Spermatozoa

Spermatogenesis begins in adolescence and the complete process takes about 74 days.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the criteria for severe acute malnutrition in a 6-month-old child?
  1. Mid-upper arm circumference
  2. Symmetrical edema
  3. Weight for height
  4. Height for age
questions.solution:
Criteria for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in a 6-month-old child are mid-upper arm circumference, symmetrical edema, and weight for height. (Option B). Height for age is not the criteria for the diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition.

The presence of any of the following confers severe acute malnutrition in children 6 to 59 months of age:

  1. Weight-for-height below -3 standard deviation (<-3SD) on the WHO Growth Standard; 
  2. Presence of bipedal edema; 
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) below 11.5 cm 

Once the child is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition, the doctor must assess for the following complication:

  1. Severe edema (+++)
  2. Low appetite (failed appetite test)
  3. Medical complications (severe anemia, pneumonia, diarrhea, dehydration, cerebral palsy, tuberculosis, HIV, heart disease, etc.)
  4. One or more danger signs as per IMNCI

If any of the complications are present, the child is diagnosed with complicated SAM and is managed inpatient in the facility. 

If the above-mentioned signs are absent, the child is diagnosed with uncomplicated SAM and supervised management at home is given.

 

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy came with the deformity shown in the given image. He has a history of supracondylar fracture of the humerus about 2 years ago. Which type of injury in such fractures commonly leads to the given deformity?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and the image showing cubitus varus deformity or gunstock deformity are suggestive of an extension-type injury.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture: Extension type > Flexion type
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures

Gartland classification (in children):

  • Type I: Undisplaced
  • Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact
  • Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex, and distal fragment could be either displaced
    • Posteromedial
    • Posterolateral
  • Type IV: Complete loss of anterior and posterior periosteal hinge making it unstable in both flexion and extension

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture. Three-point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

Nerve injury:

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type - Ulnar nerve

Vessel injury:

  • Most common vessel to be injured - brachial artery

Complications:

  • Malunion - posteromedially displaced fracture tends to develop cubitus varus (gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury - usually neuropraxia, hence transient
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome 

Treatment of supracondylar fracture:

Undisplaced fractures are immobilized at 90 degrees and neutral rotation with a cast and the arm is supported by a sling for 3 weeks.

  • Open fractures, severely displaced fractures, and fractures with vascular damage are fixed by open reduction and K-wire fixation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not act by increasing insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
The drug that does not act by increasing insulin secretion is rosiglitazone.

Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, which activates PPAR-γ receptors in adipose tissue and skeletal muscles. These are insulin sensitizers and increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in patients with type 2 diabetes. These also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase glucose uptake.

The most common adverse effects of thiazolidinediones are weight gain, fluid retention, and edema.

Other options:

Option A- Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) analog that increases insulin secretion by stimulating the pancreas. 

Option C- Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP) inhibitor. It prevents the degradation of GLP by inhibiting DPP-4. GLP-1 is an incretin that is rapidly inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase. So, inhibition of dipeptidyl peptidase enhances the action of incretins and facilitates insulin release.

Option D- Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the β cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes cell membrane to depolarize and leads to cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titers of HLA antibodies are seen in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

  • smoking
  • chronic alcohol use
  • shock, liver surgery
  • mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acting on dilator pupillae has an effect similar to that of pilocarpine on sphincter pupillae?
questions.solution:
The drug acting on dilator pupillae that has an effect similar to that of pilocarpine on sphincter papillae is tamsulosin.

Pilocarpine is a muscarinic receptor agonist which acts on the sphincter pupillae causing miosis. The drug that has to cause miosis by acting on dilator pupillae should actually inhibit the action of dilator pupillae. Dilator pupillae causes mydriasis by the α1 receptor. Therefore, to prevent the action of dilator pupillae, α1 receptor should be blocked. Tamsulosin is an α1 blocker and therefore causes miosis by inhibiting the action of dilator pupillae.

Autonomic supply of the eye:

The radial muscle of the iris called dilator pupillae is controlled by α1 adrenergic receptor. Stimulation of this receptor causes mydriasis. 

The sphincter muscle of the iris is controlled by the M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. Stimulation of these receptors causes miosis.

The ciliary muscle is supplied by the β2 adrenergic receptors as well as M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. The β2 receptors cause relaxation of the ciliary muscle, which helps in far vision, while M3 and M2 receptors cause contraction of the ciliary muscle, which helps in near vision.

Option A: Timolol is a β blocker used to treat glaucoma. It reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humor.

Option B: Physostigmine is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor. It causes constriction of sphincter pupillae causing miosis and constricts ciliary muscle blocking accommodation reflex.

Option C: Tropicamide is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. It causes cycloplegia and mydriasis by inhibiting the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle (not dilator).

Related Pearl: Effect of ANS in the Eye

  Adrenergic System Cholinergic system
  Action Receptor Action Receptor
Iris radial muscle Contraction - Mydriasis α1 --------- ---------
Iris circular muscle --------- --------- Contraction - Miosis  M3
Ciliary Muscle Relaxation – Far vision β2 Contraction – Near vision M3
Lacrimal glands Secretion + α Secretion + M3, M2

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 lady comes on the fifth day of unprotected sexual intercourse. What will be your advice for contraception for this lady?

choices.text: Two tablets of high dose OCP, repeated after 24 hours

questions.solution:
Copper IUCD should be advised for contraception for this lady.

Copper-IUD is an effective postcoital contraceptive method and can be inserted up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse. It is the most effective method for emergency contraceptives. The advantages of Copper-T as emergency contraception are as follows:

  • It can be inserted as late as 5 days after unprotected intercourse.
  • It is cheap.
  • Failure rate is 0.1%.
  • It can remain an ongoing contraceptive method for 3-5 years.

Contraindications for copper-IUD:

  • Uterine abnormality with the distorted uterine cavity
  • Acute PID, or current behavior suggesting a high risk for PID
  • Postpartum endometritis or postabortal endometritis in the past 3 months
  • Known or suspected uterine or cervical malignancy
  • Genital bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Mucopurulent cervicitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Allergy to copper
  • A previously placed IUD that has not been removed

Other options:

Option A: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg (not 0.75 mg, single dose as in the question), i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Option B: These combined oral contraceptives (COC)-containing regimens have been approved by the FDA for use as emergency contraception. Pills should be taken within 72 hours. They may be given up to 120 hours but they are effective the sooner they are taken. The combined hormonal regimen consists of two tablets of high-dose norgestrel (250 μg)-ethinyl estradiol (50 μg), repeated 12 hours later and can be given with 50 mg dimenhydrinate initially. 

Option D: Laparoscopic tubectomy is a method of permanent contraception. It is not used as an emergency contraceptive.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Burn injuries were minimal. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which causes cherry-red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry-red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Greenish-blue postmortem hypostasis is seen in poisoning due to hydrogen sulphide poisoning.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have a rapid onset because of heat.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient with breast cancer comes for her second round of chemotherapy. She reveals that she had severe vomiting during and after her first round of chemotherapy. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is not effective in controlling this patient's emesis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette shows a patient undergoing chemotherapy. A drug not effective in controlling this patient's emesis is a histamine H1 antagonist.

Classification of anti-emetic agents:

Mechanism of action Use Example

Promethazine

Histamine H1 antagonist Vestibular emesis (Motion sickness) Cyclizine

 

  • 5HT3 antagonist + dexamethasone + NK1 antagonist are used in early stages, dexamethasone+aprepitant are used in delayed emesis in case of cancer chemotherapy
  • Dronabinol is a useful agent in patients receiving cancer chemotherapy when other antiemetic medications are not effective.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding her prognosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows immunohistochemistry staining negative for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors, which is triple-negative or basal type of breast cancer. It has the worst prognosis among all the molecular subtypes.

Immunohistochemistry staining:

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors; hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor; hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

(Aggressive, has worst prognosis but shows good response to chemotherapy, high PCR rates)

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: While inspecting a crime scene of a murder case, whiskey glasses were found on the table. The latent prints from the glass can be visualized by all, except ___________.
questions.solution:
Pearson method is not used for the visualization of latent fingerprints. Pearson method is used for the estimation of stature from a skeleton. All other options given can be used for the visualization of latent prints.

Latent prints are those that are left behind through interaction of hands, palms, and feet with the environment. Occasionally, these prints are left cleanly so as to be clearly visible to the unaided eye. It is more often the case that the prints are only partially visible or not visible at all without the use of specialized fingerprint-processing methods and equipment.

Methods to enhance fingerprints:

  • Lighting - White light, photoluminescence, ultraviolet spectrum lighting
  • Physical - Dusting a surface with a fine powder of contrasting color
  • Chemical - Ninhydrin, Cyanoacrylate fuming, silver nitrate

Powders used:

  • White : Lead carbonate
  • Black  : Charcoal
  • Grey : Aluminium dust OR chalk powder + mercury

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for central precocious puberty in girls?
questions.solution:
GnRH analogs are the drug of choice for central precocious puberty in girls.

Central precocious puberty is also known as true precocious puberty or gonadotropin-dependent precocious puberty. It refers to the early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, which leads to pulsatile GnRH secretion, and increased gonadotropin production, which results in higher sex steroid levels. The causes of central precocious puberty are as follows:

  • CNS tumors (Most common cause)
  • CNS anomaly
  • CNS infection
  • Head trauma
  • Ischemia
  • Iatrogenic: radiation, chemotherapy, surgical
The goal of treatment is to reduce the psychological impacts of early pubertal development and prevent short adult height. Drugs are administered to lower the estrogen level since epiphyseal fusion is an estrogen-dependent process. Leuprolide is used as a chronic GnRH agonist in the course of treatment. This substance serves as the GnRH release's initial stimulation. The GnRH receptor becomes desensitized over time. This finally limits the secretion of FSH and LH by downregulating pituitary gonadotropes. Because of this, estrogen levels fall, and breast and uterine sizes frequently retreat.
 
Danazol has a very helpful clinical effect in regulating the growth of secondary sexual traits, but it has no effect on the condition's rapid linear growth and skeletal maturation.

Cyproterone and medroxyprogesterone acetate are effective in delaying the onset of puberty, but they have been proven to have no positive effects on final height results.

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The histological features shown in the image below are seen in:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the histology of tonsils with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and lymphoid nodules in the center.

The tonsil consists of lymphoid nodules, which are surrounded by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium on its oropharyngeal surface. The epithelium dips into the substance of the gland and forms tonsillar crypts.

The following image shows the histology of the tonsils:

 

Histology of thymus (option A):

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

 

Structure of a lymph node (option B):

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

 

Structure of spleen (Option D):

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue:

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: Shown below is a section taken from a specimen of an adrenal gland. Which of the following results in a decrease in the hormone exclusively secreted by the layer marked as '1'?
questions.solution:
In the above image, the layer marked as '1' is zona glomerulosa, and aldosterone is exclusively secreted by this layer. Hypernatremia decreases aldosterone secretion. 

The zona glomerulosa is a thin layer of cells that lies just underneath the capsule of the adrenal gland.

The following factors are known to play roles in the regulation of aldosterone: 

  • Hyperkalemia increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Increased angiotensin II concentration increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Hypernatremia concentration in the extracellular fluid slightly decreases aldosterone secretion.
  • ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland is necessary for aldosterone secretion but has minimal effect in physiological conditions.
  • Increased sodium ion concentration in the extracellular fluid decreases aldosterone secretion.

Other options:

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone)
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol)
  • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids

The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with a white reflex came to the OPD. A histopathological examination showed the following picture and a tumor involving more than half of the retina. What is the most common mode of spread of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retinoblastoma, and direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. 

It arises from the neurosensory retina. It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. Tumors are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat’s eye. Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis. If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

  • The quiescent stage - lasts from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage - Results in the enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.  
  • The stage of extraocular extension.
  • The stage of metastasis.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific to retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma is through direct invasion. It can invade the optic nerve and spread to the brain, or it can also directly spread to the sclera or orbit.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide are the choice of drugs for chemotherapy. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when the tumor involves more than half of the retina, optic nerve involvement, glaucoma, and anterior chamber involvement.

Related Pearl: Reese Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

questions.text: In genomic imprinting, DNA is modified by _______.
questions.solution:
Imprinting of DNA occurs by methylation of CpG island.

Epigenetic modification are heritable chemical modification of DNA or chromatin that does not alter the protein-encoding DNA sequence itself. The expression of a gene (protein structure) may be altered. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. 

Imprinting is one such epigenetic modification where DNA is methylated selectively inactivating either the maternal or the paternal allele. Maternal imprinting results in transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, and paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

Epigenetic modification of core histones includes acetylation, deacetylation and methylation. Acetylation of specific lysine residues facilitates an open structure and permits access to transcription factors for interaction with DNA. Methylation of histone lysine residues can lead to transcriptional activation or repression.

questions.text: A schematic representation of the development of various vessels of the head and neck is given below. Which of the following is true regarding the abnormal right subclavian artery?

choices.text: Obliteration of A with persistence of B
Obliteration of B with persistence of A

questions.solution:
The abnormal right subclavian artery is formed by the obliteration of the right fourth aortic arch and the proximal portion of the right dorsal aorta (marked B), with the persistence of the distal portion of the right dorsal aorta (marked A).

Normally, the right subclavian artery is formed proximally by the right 4th aortic arch. The distal part is formed by a portion of the right dorsal aorta and the right 7th intersegmental artery. The right dorsal aorta is obliterated between the origin of the seventh intersegmental artery and the junction with the left dorsal aorta.

The derivatives of the various aortic arches are described in the pearl below:

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Tropical spastic paraparesis is caused by ______.
questions.solution:
Human T-lymphotropic virus-1 (HTLV1) is the causative agent of a neurodegenerative disorder called HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).

  • The condition resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness or stiffness in one or both legs,
  • The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and extensor plantar response.
  • The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of thoracic myelopathy.

Other conditions caused by HTLV-1:

  • Adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL)
  • Uveitis
  • Dermatitis
  • Arthritis
  • Sjögren’s syndrome

questions.text: A patient underwent an imaging study; the findings are shown in the image given below. Which of the following compounds is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously. This compound is taken up and broken down in the cells.

It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

Applications of PET:

  • Oncologic:
    • Detection, staging, drug response
    • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence
  • Neurologic:
    • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
    • Localization of seizure focus in the interictal phase
    • Localizing eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)
  • Cardiac:
    • Identification of hibernating myocardium

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of ischemic heart disease.  His ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows atrial fibrillation. On physical examination of his jugular venous pressure, absent 'a' waves will be noted. 

The following features in the ECG strip suggest the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation:

  • Presence of fibrillatory 'f' waves is indicative of uncoordinated atrial activation. Normal morphology P waves (indicative of normal atrial contraction) are absent
  • The QRS complex duration is <120 ms, which is normal. A narrow QRS complex indicates that the impulses are originating from the atria
  • R waves (QRS complex) occur irregularly, indicative of a variable RR interval. The rhythm is irregular (the pace is set by the refractory period of the AV node)

The 'a' wave is the first peak on a JVP tracing. It represents the atrial contraction (atrial systole). The rapid impulses of atrial fibrillation do not allow enough time for atrial filling and atrial contraction, leading to absent 'a' waves on JVP. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate

Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)

questions.text: A patient presents with long-standing dyspnea, abdominal distension and pain. The gross appearance of his liver is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Nutmeg liver with dark areas of pericentral dead hepatocytes and pale areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver induced due to OCPs
Nutmeg liver with pale areas of necrosis and dark congested areas of pericentral viable hepatocytes

questions.solution:
The gross image of the liver shows a nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and grey areas of periportal viable hepatocytes.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes the following:

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein 
  • Bile duct

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava. 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area 
  • Zone 2 is the intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the pericentral area, closest to the central vein

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, which is known as a nutmeg liver. 

Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver is due to cirrhosis from chronic liver failure. Common causes include chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, alcoholic and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. It is characterised by parenchymal nodules surrounded by dense bands of fibrosis throughout the liver, bumpy surface with depressed areas of scarring and bulging regenerative nodules.

questions.text: A patient presenting to emergency due to bronchospasm and angioedema is administered adrenaline. Which of the following actions of adrenaline does not contribute to its effects in this scenario?

choices.text: Action on blood vessels via alpha-receptors

questions.solution:
Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors is not a mechanism of adrenaline in case of anaphylaxis.

Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α and β adrenergic receptors. It is a physiological antagonist of histamine which is a mediator of acute hypersensitivity reactions. Adrenaline is life-saving in case of laryngeal edema and anaphylaxis. The vasoconstrictor, cardiac stimulant, and bronchodilator actions contribute to these effects.

  • Adrenaline increases heart rate and force of cardiac contraction primarily through β1 receptor
  • The α receptors (both α1 and α2) cause vasoconstriction in the precapillary arterioles increasing peripheral vascular resistance and blood pressure. This reduces any tissue edema that has developed as a result of the increased vascular permeability.
  • It is a potent bronchodilator by acting on β2 receptor that is more marked when the bronchi are constricted in case of anaphylaxis.

Presynaptic α2 receptors on nerve endings are responsible for the inhibition of neurotransmitter release and decreased central sympathetic flow.

Related Pearl: Effects of ANS on blood vessels

questions.text: Which of the following about hallux valgus is false?

choices.text: There is lateral deviation of the great toe
Angle between the first and second metatarsals is more than 8 to 9 degrees

questions.solution:
It is caused due to the excessive lateral deviation of the great toe with the prominence of the head of the first metatarsal. Often, there is also deformity of the lesser toes and pain in the forefoot. 

It can be congenital or a consequence of rheumatoid arthritis or excessive usage of footwear with narrow toe space.

The angle between the first and second metatarsals is more than the normal 8 to 9 degrees. The valgus angle of the first metatarsophalangeal joint also is more than the normal 15 to 20. If the valgus angle of the first metatarsophalangeal joint exceeds 30 to 35 degrees, pronation of the great toe usually results.

The following image shows bunionplasty for hallus valgus: Before & After clinical images and radiographs demonstrate a bunionplasty plastic closure so that the scar is minimal.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is best used to assess the eustachian tube function in patients with intact or perforated tympanic membranes?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is a test used to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction in patients with an intact or perforated tympanic membrane (TM). It is an objective measure of ET function. Although politzerization can be used, tympanometry is better than politzerization.

Tympanometry allows for the visualization of the changes in the movement of TM in response to variations in external canal pressure. The disadvantage of this method is that middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

Other tests of ET function include Toynbee’s test, phototubometry, saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears, and sonotubometry.

Politzerization (Option C) is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, scarring of ET, epistaxis, and the spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear.

The other listed procedures (Options A and B) are used for ET function testing, but they are done in cases where the tympanic membrane is intact.
