questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. What is the most likely distance range of the shot?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central rat-hole with peripheral satellite pellet holes appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun. So it was most likely shot at a distance range of 1-5 meters. 

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

  • Soft tissues -
    • Single circular wound, often with muzzle imprint
    • The diameter of the wound is approximately the same as that of the muzzle.
    • No soot soiling, tattooing, singeing
  • Bone
    • Same as that of soft tissues, but wound may be split and ragged due to gas rebound

<30 cm

  • Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling
  • Burnt hairs - singeing
  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles - tattooing

30 cm to 1 m

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes
  • Soot soiling
  • Powder tattooing

1–5 meters

  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes
  • No soot, tattooing +/-

>5 meters

  • Diffuse pellet pattern
  • No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing

questions.text: Which among the following tests is not used for neonatal screening of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, distraction techniques are not used for neonatal screening of hearing loss. 

Distraction techniques are used in children of age 6-7 months. High-frequency sounds, low-frequency sounds, whispered sounds and warbled tones are used to distract the child. The child responds by turning the head toward the source of sound if the hearing is intact.

Other options: 

Option B: Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It is an objective test of hearing. They can be used as screening tests for hearing in neonates. It can be used to diagnose neuropathy of the 8th cranial nerve. OAEs are absent in conditions like middle ear effusion and non-functional outer hair cells in the cochlea.

Option C: Arousal test is used for screening neonatal hearing. Here, when the infant is in light sleep, high-frequency narrow-band noise is presented for 2 seconds. An infant with normal hearing is aroused from sleep twice when three such stimuli are given.   

Option D: Auditory response cradle test is used for screening neonatal hearing. In this, the behaviour of the baby lying in the cradle is monitored using transducers in response to auditory stimuli. It can identify infants with moderate, severe, or profound hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text:
A known amount of heavy water and inulin are injected intravenously into a healthy young male. The volume of distribution of heavy water and inulin is 36 liters and 12 liters, respectively. Which of the following estimations are true about this condition?
  1. Total body water is 36 L
  2. Intracellular fluid volume is 12 L
  3. Extracellular fluid volume is 9 L
  4. Plasma volume is 3 L
  5. Volume of interstitial fluid is 6 L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, total body water of the person is around 36 L, and plasma volume is around 3 L. So, statements 1 and 4 are true.

Step 1- Find volumes of total body water and ECF.

Heavy water measures the total body water, whereas inulin measures the extracellular fluid (ECF). Therefore, in this person, total body water is 36 L, and the ECF volume is 12 L.

Step 2- Calculate intracellular fluid (ICF).

ICF = total body water - ECF

Therefore, ICF volume in this person is 24 L.

Step 3- Calculate the plasma volume and volume of the interstitial fluid.

Interstitial fluid constitutes three-fourth of the ECF and plasma volume constitutes one-fourth of ECF. Therefore, the volume of plasma is 1/4th of 12 L, which is 3 L, and the volume of interstitial fluid is 3/4th of 12 L, which is 9 L.

Related Pearl: Indicators for measurement of body fluids

Compartments

Indicators

Plasma volume
  • Evans’ blue(T1824)
  • Human serum albumin tagged with radioactive iodine125

RBC volume

Tagging RBC with cr-51, Fe-59, 32P, also antigenic tagging

ECF volume
  • Inulin
  • Sucrose
  • Mannitol
  • Sodium thiosulphate
  • Sodium thiocyanate

Interstitial fluid

Cannot be measured directly.

ECF minus plasma volume gives the value

ICF

Cannot be measured directly.

TBW minus ECF gives the value (D2O minus Mannitol)

TBW

D2O (2H2O)

Tritium oxide (3H2O)

Antipyrine

Aminopyrine

questions.text: A new vaccine that was in the clinical trial phase of efficacy confirmation for COVID-19 has been approved for marketing by the FDA. The following statements about the post-marketing surveillance phase of the clinical trial are true, except that ______.

choices.text: The main aim of this phase is to identify adverse events, compliance, and drug interactions.
It is a randomized controlled type of trial.
It involves thousands to lakhs of participants.
There is no fixed duration for completion of this phase.

questions.solution:
The postmarketing surveillance (Phase IV) of the clinical trial is an open-label type and not a randomized controlled type of trial. 

Phase IV- Postmarketing surveillance of clinical trials is started when the phase III trial is completed and a new drug application (NDA) is approved by the FDA. The approved drug is prescribed to patients all around the world. Patients treated in the normal course form the study population therefore numbers are larger.

Uncommon/ idiosyncratic adverse effects, occurring after long-term use, unsuspected drug interactions, and compliance are detected at this stage.

The participants/ patients in this phase are not controlled or randomized to a study and control population; hence, it is not a randomized control trial (RCT). It is an open-label trial as all the patients who receive the drug are aware of the intake of drugs and not blinded. There is no fixed duration as to when this phase ends.

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done.

questions.text: Which of the following is not present under Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme?

choices.text: Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation
Mandatory provision of iron- and folic acid–fortified foods in government-funded health programmes
Testing of anemia using Sahli's method

questions.solution:
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme testing of anemia using Sahli's method is not done. Testing of anemia in pregnant women and adolescent schools will be done using digital hemoglobinometers.

The 6 interventions of Anemia Mukt Bharath scheme are as follows:

  1. Prophylactic iron and folic acid (IFA) supplementation to children, adolescents, and women of reproductive age and pregnant women irrespective of anemia.
  2. Bi-annual mass deworming for children in the age groups between 1-19 years
  3. Behavior change communication campaign, including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns
  4. Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment
  5. Mandatory provision of iron- and folic acid–fortified foods in government-funded health programs
  6. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the direct branches of the external carotid artery?
  1. Inferior thyroid artery
  2. Lingual artery
  3. Occipital artery
  4. Pre-auricular artery
  5. Maxillary artery
  6. Deep temporal artery
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the branches of the external carotid artery (ECA) are the lingual artery, occipital artery, and maxillary artery.

The 8 branches of the external carotid artery are as follows:

  • Anterior branches:
    • Superior thyroid artery
    • Lingual artery
    • Facial artery
  • Posterior branches:
    • Occipital artery
    • Posterior auricular artery
  • Medial branch:
    • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Terminal branches:
    • Maxillary artery
    • Superficial temporal artery

The following dissected image shows the branches of ECA:

The following image shows the branches of common carotid artery:

Other options:

Inferior thyroid artery: It is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which, in turn, arises from the front of the first part of the subclavian artery.

Deep temporal artery: It is a branch of the maxillary artery, which is, in turn, a branch of the external carotid artery(ECA). It is to be noted that the deep temporal artery is not a direct branch of the ECA.

Related Pearl: Internal carotid artery branches

Part
Course

Cervical part
Originates from the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. It has a dilation at the lower end which is known as carotid sinus. It ascends in front of the transverse process of the upper three cervical vertebrae.

Petrous part
Passes through the carotid canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Caroticotympanic branch

Cavernous part

  • Meningeal branch

  • Ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior choroidal artery
  • Posterior communicating artery

The petrous, cavernous and intracranial parts of the internal carotid artery are called the carotid siphon because of its sigmoid course.

questions.text: The most important regulator of iron absorption is ________.
questions.solution:
The most important regulator of iron absorption is hepcidin.

Body iron stores are controlled by intestinal absorption as there is no exit to iron from the body. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) transport non-heme iron into the enterocyte.

Iron absorption in the duodenum is regulated by hepcidin release from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It binds to ferroportin leading to endocytosis and degradation within the enterocyte. This prevents the transfer of iron from enterocyte to plasma resulting in iron trapping within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin. The trapped iron is lost as these cells are sloughed. 

The iron transported by ferroportin into the plasma is transferred to other parts with help of transferrin and stored as serum ferritin and hemosiderin.

This regulation by hepcidin is affected in the case of

  • Anaemia of chronic disease where hepcidin is increased leading to reduced iron absorption and also release from macrophages, an important source of the iron that is used to make haemoglobin.
  • Hepcidin activity is low in the case of hemochromatosis leading to systemic iron overload.

The absorption of iron is depicted in the image below:

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for the induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and 3 cm long. The vertex is at -1 station, and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the modified Bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:
The modified Bishop score in this patient is calculated to be 6.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, length, position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) system, effacement is replaced by the cervical length in centimeters.

From the data given in the question:

  • The position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0
  • Cervical length is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • The station of the head is -1, hence score = 2

Hence, the modified Bishop score is 0+1+1+2+2 = 6.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman diagnosed with Graves' disease was started on an anti-thyroid drug. All the following are potentially severe side effects of the thioamide group of antithyroid drugs, except _____.
questions.solution:
The side effect not associated with the thioamide group of antithyroid drugs is anaphylaxis. 

Propylthiouracil, methimazole, and carbimazole are antithyroid drugs of the thioamide type. They prevent hormone synthesis by inhibiting reactions catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. This inhibits the incorporation of iodine into tyrosyl residues of thyroglobulin and also inhibits the coupling of these iodotyrosyl residues.

The most common reaction is an urticarial papular rash that often subsides spontaneously but sometimes requires an antihistamine and corticosteroids and changing to another antithyroid drug.

Agranulocytosis is the most serious reaction. Patients should be instructed to immediately report the development of sore throat or fever and should discontinue their antithyroid drug and obtain a granulocyte count.

In pregnancy, propylthiouracil is used in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy. Methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown above is marbling.

The blood in the vessels is hemolyzed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin becomes prominent about 36–48 hours after death in summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest branch of the artery marked in the image as 'X'?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the vertebral artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is its largest branch.

The vertebral artery is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery. It enters the skull through the foramen magnum and terminates by joining the vertebral artery on the opposite side forming the basilar artery. The branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery are:

  • Meningeal branches - supplying dura of posterior cranial fossa
  • Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
  • Anterior spinal arteries - supply the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.
  • Medullary branches - supplying the medulla

Clinical importance - A disruption in blood supply in the PICA leads to lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man involved in a fight injured his finger, and the deformity is shown in the following image. X-ray is normal. Which of the following anatomical structures are involved?
questions.solution:
Based on the mechanism of injury and flexion at the DIP, as seen in the clinical image, the diagnosis is mallet finger. It is due to the avulsion of the distal part of the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint. 

Mallet finger is commonly known as the baseball finger because the injury often happens when playing baseball. Damage to the tendon occurs when a hard ball (that the patient was trying to catch or field) hit the fingertip.

It is treated by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger.

 

Jersey finger is caused by the rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus from the distal phalanx. It occurs when there is hyperextension of the flexed finger trapped in a jersey. On physical examination, the finger lies in slight extension relative to other fingers in the resting position and no active flexion of DIP is possible.

questions.text: In a group of 100 people, the average GFR is 85 mL/min with a standard deviation (SD) of 25, what is the range for a 90% confidence interval?
questions.solution:
The range for a 90% confidence interval in this study is 81-89 mL/min.

In a normal curve, the area on either side of the mean will include approximately

  • 68% of the values in the distribution between 1 SD
  • 95% of the values in the distribution between 2 SD
  • 99.7% of the values in the distribution between 3 SD

These limits on either side of the mean are called confidence intervals (CI). The confidence interval for this study can be calculated as follows:

z for 90% CI is 1.64. The standard error of mean (SEM) comes out as 25/√100=2.5.

Substituting the values in the above formula, we get CI= 85±1.64*2.5, which is 81-89 mL/min.

Confidence level Critical (z) value
75% 1.15
90% 1.64
95% 1.95
99% 2.57

(Alternatively, the CI for 95% can be found as 85±2*2.5= 80-90. In the case of normal distribution, reducing the range of CI from 95% to 90% shortens the interval to stay in-between 80-90, which is option A in this case)

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: A transplant recipient is kept on immunosuppressive therapy for 1 year. On follow-up visits, there is a steady rise in serum creatinine levels over a period of four months. A tissue biopsy is taken. Which of the following complement factors is a marker of humoral rejection?
questions.solution:
The complement factor which is a marker of humoral rejection is C4d

Acute antibody-mediated rejection: It is manifested mainly by damage to glomeruli and small blood vessels. There is inflammation of the glomeruli and peritubular capillaries, associated with deposition of complement products due to activation of the complement system by the antibody-dependent classical pathway

Chronic antibody-mediated rejection: It manifests as interstitial fibrosis and graft arteriosclerosis-gradual narrowing of graft blood vessels.

Immunoperoxidase stain shows C4d deposition in peritubular capillaries and a glomerulus.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are false about transfusion-associated malaria?
  1. Sporozoite is the infective stage of the parasite.
  2. Pre-erythrocytic stage is not present.
  3. It may be associated with severe complications and relapses.
  4. It has a shorter incubation period compared to mosquito-borne malaria.
  5. It requires radical treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3 and 5 are false. In transfusion-associated malaria, trophozoite is the infective stage (1). It does not show relapses (3) and does not require radical treatment (5).

Transfusion-transmitted malaria:

  • This condition occurs when a person rcieves blood infected with the malarial parasite.
  • The parasite may survive in stored blood for 1 to 2 weeks.
  • Unlike mosquito-borne malaria where sporozoites enter the blood,here transfused RBCs containing the trophozoites enter the patient’s (recipient’s) blood directly. Hence, there is no pre-erythrocytic stage and the incubation period is usually shorter than mosquito-borne malaria.
  • The patient may develop severe complications.
  • However, hypnozoites are absent and there are no relapses, hence no radical treatment is required.

Other conditions where the trophozoites directly cause the infection include: congenital malaria (due to transplacental transmission from mother to fetus), renal transplantation, and shared syringes among drug addicts.

Related Pearl: Comparison between mosquito-borne and transfusion-transmitted malaria.

  Mosquito-borne malaria Transfusion transmitted malaria
Mode of transmission Mosquito bite Transfusion of infected blood or blood products
Infective stage Sporozoite Trophozoite
Pre-erythrocytic stage Present Absent
Incubation period Long Short  
Complications Comparatively less Associated with severe complications
Hypnozoites May be seen in infection with P. vivax and ovale Absent
Relapse May occur Does not occur
Radical treatment Required Not required

questions.text:
Which of the following are immune complex–mediated hypersensitivity reactions?
  1. Serum sickness
  2. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
  3. Myasthenia gravis
  4. Polyarteritis nodosa
  5. Systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reactions are 1, 2, 4, and 5.

Type III hypersensitivity reaction, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, is due to the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes leading to complement activation. Immune complex-mediated diseases tend to be systemic, but often preferentially involve the kidney (glomerulonephritis), joints (arthritis), and small blood vessels (vasculitis). Examples of immune complex-mediated diseases are:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction 

Myasthenia gravis is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that is antibody-mediated. In type II hypersensitivity, antibodies that react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following except__________
questions.solution:
Polysomnography contains all of the above except arterial Pco2 measurement.

Polysomnography is used to study sleep and its associated phenomena. It is usually the preferred method in sleep research centers. It consists of the following:

  • Continuous EEG recording, from occipital and parietal leads
  • Electro-oculography- to record eye movements
  • Electromyography- for muscle potential and its activities
  • ECG
  • Multiple sleep latency tests- repeated measures of time taken to sleep
  • Nasal-oral airflow, respiratory effort, oxyhemoglobin saturation, and leg movements during sleep are measured.

questions.text: A woman comes to the casualty at 18 weeks of gestation with complaints of vaginal bleeding. She has a history of two early pregnancy losses. USG reveals the absence of fetal cardiac activity. Which of the following investigations need not be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent abortions, and extensive infection workup is not done.

Even though recurrent abortions are defined as ≥3 pregnancy losses, investigations must be done after 2 consecutive losses.

Diagnostic evaluation of recurrent pregnancy loss based on etiology is given as follows:

Etiology  Diagnostic evaluation 
Genetic  Parental karyotyping 
Anatomic 

Hysterosalpingography

Ultrasound

Saline-infusion sonography 
Endocrine 

TSH

Testing for insulin resistance

Serum prolactin level

Ovarian reserve testing

Antithyroid antibodies 
Infectious  No evaluation is recommended unless the patient has evidence of chronic endometritis/cervicitis on examination, or is immunocompromised 
Autoimmune 

Anticardiolipin antibody levels (IgG and IgM) 

Lupus anticoagulant   

Homocysteine

Factor V Leiden

Prothrombin promoter mutation

Activated protein C resistance

questions.text: A female patient presents with a history of high-grade fever for the last 5 days. She was recently diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination, a new regurgitant murmur is heard. She is suspected to have infective endocarditis. According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture for which organism is included in the major criteria?
questions.solution:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800 is included in the major criteria.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: All of the following processes primarily take place in mitochondria, except _______.
questions.solution:
All of the listed processes take place in mitochondria, except fatty acid synthesis.

Fatty acids are synthesized by an extramitochondrial system, which is responsible for the complete synthesis of palmitate from acetyl-CoA in the cytosol. The main pathway for the de novo synthesis of fatty acid occurs in the cytosol. Lipogenesis requires cofactors that include NADPH, ATP, manganese, biotin, and HCO3– (as a source of CO2).

Ketogenesis, beta-oxidation of fatty acids, and citric acid cycle occur primarily in the mitochondria.

Related Pearl: Biosynthesis of Fatty acids

Related Pearl: Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids

Note: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1) is also known as carnitine acyltransferase I,

Related Pearl: Sites of various pathways in cell

Sites of metabolism

Mitochondria

Fatty acid oxidation (βoxidation)

Acetyl CoA production

TCA Cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

Ketogenesis

Cytoplasm

Glycolysis

HMP Shunt

Synthesis of steroids(SER)

Proteins (RER and Ribosomes)

Fatty acids

Cholesterol

Nucleotides

Both

Heme synthesis

Urea cycle

Gluconeogenesis

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of hypopigmented lesions, with occasional itching. The lesions appear as shown in the given image. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of vitiligo, and betamethasone, a corticosteroid, is used as a first-line treatment. 

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of the skin. 

Vitiligo is classified as shown below:


Vitiligo (Non segmental)
  • Acrofacial
  • Mucosal (>1 one mucosal site)
  • Generalized
  • Universal
  • Mixed (associated with SV)
  • Rare variants
Segmental vitiligo
  • Uni-, bi-, or pleuri-segmental

Undetermined/

unclassified vitiligo
  • Focal
  • Mucosal (one site in isolation)

Vitiligo is associated with a number of autoimmune disorders: 

  • Thyroid disease - strongest association
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Alopecia areata

The lesions become apparent at 20-30 years of age. Hypopigmented macules occur in areas of repeated friction commonly in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin in patients with skin disorders like vitiligo. Ivory or milky-white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is seen in vitiligo.

Treatment:

  • The topical application of corticosteroids - Potent corticosteroids such as betamethasone and clobetasol is applied to reinduce pigmentation. These are the common first-line drugs. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus are also used as first-line drugs mainly for the lesions on the neck and the face.
  • Second-line treatment includes systemic psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA), khellin, and narrow-band ultraviolet B therapy (NB-UVB).

Surgical grafting techniques can be used in patients who do not respond to this treatment in stable vitiligo, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non-pigmented area. Full‐thickness punch grafts, split‐thickness grafts, suction blister grafts) and cellular grafts (cultured melanocytes, cultured epithelial sheet grafts, and non‐cultured epidermal cellular grafts) are used.

Depigmentation can be done in patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left. Skin bleaching with laser therapy, cryotherapy, and hydroquinone may be used.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, a shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous haemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina. 

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision
  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Senile cataract
  • Primary open angle glaucoma
  • Optic atrophy
  • ARMD
  • Refractive error
  • Diabetic retinopathy
Gradual painful diminution of vision
  • Chronic iridocyclitis
  • Corneal ulceration

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below?

RS cell: Reed-Sternberg cell

HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus

CMV: Cytomegalovirus

EBV: Epstein-Barr virus
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis, cell, and virus from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological image are Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) respectively.

Hodgkin's lymphoma arises in a single lymph node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

RS cells are giant neoplastic cells derived from germinal centre or post–germinal centre B cells. They appear as large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes. Each cell contains large inclusion-like prominent nucleoli, and abundant, usually slightly eosinophilic, cytoplasm, depicting an owl-eye appearance, as shown in the image below.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  • Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+ and EB -.

Type RS-cell EB Virus Prognosis
1. Nodular sclerosis (most common in the world) Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells Rare Very good
2. Mixed cellularity (most common in India) Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells 70% Good
3.Lymphocyte Rich

Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells

 40% Very good
4.Lymphocyte depleted Reticular variant: frequent diagnostic RS cells and variants and a paucity of background reactive cell 90%(Max) Poorest

5.Lymphocyte predominant		 L&H variant (Popcorn cell) variants in the background of follicular dendritic cells 0%(Min) Excellent

The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Other options: 

Option A: RS cells are diagnostic of Hodgkin's lymphoma, not non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The histopathologic findings in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) are varied and depend on the subtype.

Option B: Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus. Cutaneous lesions of Kaposi sarcoma are composed of spindle cells, mostly in the dermis or subcutaneous tissues, with small vessels and slit-like spaces with red cells.

The image shows lesions seen in Kaposi's sarcoma.

Option D: Infectious mononucleosis is caused by EBV. The peripheral blood smear shows absolute lymphocytosis with mononucleosis cells which are atypical activated T lymphocytes. They have abundant cytoplasm with multiple vacuolations and azurophilic granules, and an oval, indented, or folded nucleus and are shown below.

About 5-7% of the cases of infectious mononucleosis can be caused by the cytomegalovirus (CMV), which can also cause pneumonia. CMV-infected pneumocytes with large, intranuclear, basophilic inclusions with haloes at their periphery as well as small, granular cytoplasmic inclusions are seen below with an owl-eye appearance.

Related Pearl: Hodgkin v/s Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

Features Hodgkin Lymphoma  Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Lymph nodes  Single axial group of lymph nodes Multiple peripheral lymph nodes 
Spread Contiguous Non-contiguous
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring  Rarely involved Commonly involved
Extra-nodal involvement Uncommon  Common

Related Pearl: Types of giant cells

Giant cells Seen in
Langhans giant cells TB Granuloma
Reed Sternberg cells Hodgkin lymphoma
Aschoff giant cells Rheumatic fever
Touton giant cells

Juvenile xanthogranuloma,

Xanthoma disseminatum,

dermatofibroma
Warthin Finkeldey giant cells Measles
Physiological giant cells Bone marrow osteoclast cells and megakaryocytes

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: The image below shows the EEG recordings during sleep. Which of the following recordings corresponds to the stage of sleep when it is most difficult to wake a person up?
questions.solution:
The stage of sleep characterized by the deepest sleep when it is hardest to wake a patient is Stage 3 NREM sleep as depicted by the high-amplitude delta rhythm in image 3.

Sleep is made up of two physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. REM sleep is characterized by a high level of brain activity. REM sleep refers to rapid, roving eye movements that occur during this stage of sleep and are recorded as an electrooculogram (EOG). During REM sleep, except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is increased during this time. 

NREM sleep is composed of stages 1 through 4. About 90 minutes after sleep onset, NREM yields to the first REM episode of the night. Non-REM sleep is divided into four stages:

Stage 1: The transition from wakefulness to sleep. EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed-frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) is seen during this stage with vertex sharp waves. There are slow eye movements.

Stage 2: Presence of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz) and K complexes which are negative sharp waves followed by a positive slow wave. There are no eye movements, muscle tone is reduced. (image 2)

Stage 3: Presence of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz). There is a further reduction in muscle tone and arousal, no eye movements. (image 3)

Stage 4: A characteristic pattern of rhythmic slow waves, sometimes referred to as slow-wave sleep. Occurrence of theta and delta rhythms is normal during sleep. No eye movements, low muscle tone.

Wakefulness: Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is noted. (image 1) Eye movements and eye blinks are present, with high muscle tonic activity and voluntary movements.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with slowly progressive swelling and pain in the right leg. His x-ray of the right leg is given below. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with slowly progressing swelling and pain in the leg, x-ray showing multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis, and epithelial cells seen in a fibrous stroma on microscopy is suggestive of adamantinoma.

Adamantinoma is a rare malignant tumor. Most cases appear in the lower extremities and classically in the tibial diaphysis. It is most often seen in the second to fourth decade of life. The patient usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling. Intralesional or marginal excision causes local recurrence, so complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice. 

The image below shows an x-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.

Option B - Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution—at adolescence and in the seventh decade. It is typically seen in metaphyseal regions of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. 

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance. Microscopy shows osteoid production from malignant spindle cells and marked nuclear pleomorphism.

The x-ray below shows the sunburst appearance of osteosarcoma.

Option C - Osteoclastoma also known as giant cell tumor (GCT). It is a locally aggressive benign neoplasm, most often seen between 20-40 years of age. Most of the cases appear in the epiphysis of lower extremities, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Microscopy shows multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells.

Rarely malignant transformations may occur in GCT. 

The image below shows an x-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

Option D - Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm most often seen in men aged 10-20 years. Most of the cases appear in the lower extremities commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and gets relieved on aspirin. Microscopy shows a central nidus composed of highly vascularized bone and intertwined osteoid. 

The below x-ray shows osteoid osteoma demonstrating a zone of dense sclerosis surrounding a radiolucent nidus.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of aphasia seen in patients after head trauma?
questions.solution:
Anomic aphasia is the most common type of aphasia in metabolic encephalopathy, Alzheimer's disease, and head trauma.

Articulation, comprehension, and repetition remain intact but the patient has word-finding, naming, and spelling difficulty.

Naming can be tested by asking the person to name multiple objects. The patient might not be able to identify the object at all or may be able to identify it but may not be able to name it. He might answer in a circumstantial paraphrase or a semantic paraphrase.

questions.text: A 44-year-old cave explorer presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Findings of microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage are shown below. Identify the organism and the stain used.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black stained cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. The chest x-ray is normal in case of mild symptoms and shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric in later stages. Pneumatocele and pneumothorax are characteristic chest radiographic findings. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) or pentamidine is the treatment. HIV patients with CD4 count <200/μL should be started on prophylaxis with TMP-SMX.

Histoplasma capsulatum spreads by inhalation of spores from bat or bird droppings. It causes flu-like illness, anorexia, dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. X-ray shows signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy and not pneumatocele. It is also stained with methenamine silver or Giemsa stain.

questions.text: A patient with an established diagnosis of peptic ulcer disease is started on omeprazole. Which type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Primary active transport type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that blocks the H+-K+ ATPase. The proton pump is an example of primary active transport. 

Primary active transport is an active transport mechanism that obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient. The transportation of the molecules mainly depends on the carrier proteins.

Important examples of primary active transport: 

  • Sodium-potassium ATPase
  • Proton pump
  • Calcium ATPase

Proton pumps: These are essential for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. These pumps are mainly present in gastric glands of the stomach and late distal tubules and cortical collecting ducts of the kidney. 

The main function of proton pumps in the parietal cells of the stomach is to secrete gastric acid. The gastric mucosa has abundant mitochondria and this provides the ATPase that is required for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. 

At rest, the proton pumps lie within the cells in stacks of membrane compartments called tubulovesicles. During the active phase secretion, these tubulovesicles fuse to form canaliculi. This fusion increases the apical membrane of the cells and positions the proton pumps to begin the acid secretion. 

Proton-pump inhibitors like omeprazole form thiophilic sulfenamide cation that irreversibly binds and inactivates the enzyme H+-K+ ATPase. 

Other options: 

Option A: In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option B: In secondary active transport, the transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances against the concentration gradient. Examples include sodium co-transport of glucose and amino acids with sodium and sodium counter-transport of calcium and hydrogen ions. 

Option C: In facilitated diffusion, the molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy. Examples include the transport of glucose through GLUT (insulin-mediated transport of glucose via GLUT 4). 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with dry mouth and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination reveals enlargement of her parotid glands, along with marked dryness of her buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal gland is a major target for this disease

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth; difficulty swallowing solid food; and the findings of enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibody positivity for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren syndrome. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis.

Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.

Antibodies detected are:

  • Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present
  • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs)
  • SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis
  • SS-B (La)

These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder.

Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren syndrome.

The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland.

Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection?

choices.text: Diagnosis is made using urine specimen at 4 weeks of age.
In developing countries, congenital CMV infection is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
30-40% of newborns with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth.
CMV is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL in children.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding CMV infection is that congenital CMV infection is the most common cause of non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).

Congenital infection with CMV is mostly asymptomatic, and symptomatic infections can occur in about 10% of newborns (Option C). The vast majority of the cases of congenital CMV throughout the world follow nonprimary maternal infections (Option B).

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Laboratory findings include direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated hepatic transaminases, and thrombocytopenia. A non-contrast CT scan shows periventricular calcifications. Prenatal diagnosis includes the presence of IgM antibodies in the mother or the fetal diagnosis by detecting the virus through the amniotic fluid polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Postnatal diagnosis involves isolation of the virus from the urine or saliva via the DNA PCR or culture within the first 2-3 weeks of life (Option A).

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with oral ganciclovir for 6 months could reduce the extent of hearing loss. Oral valganciclovir can also be used. Regular follow-ups should be done particularly, hearing screening tests. 

Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

questions.text: A  patient comes with complaints of fever, cough with foul-smelling sputum, and night sweats. She reported having undergone a tooth extraction a few days ago. On examination, clubbing is seen and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung.  Her chest x-ray is shown below. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The diganosis is lung abscess. 

The clinical points pointing to the diagnosis in this case are 

  • History of fever, cough with foul-smelling discharge, and night sweats
  • History of tooth extraction pointing towards the possibility of aspiration
  • Clubbing and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung
  • Chest X-ray image showing a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level.

Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:

  • Primary lung abscess usually occurs in the absence of any underlying systemic or pulmonary condition. They usually occur in the posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of the lungs. The right lung is more commonly involved because of less angulated right mainstem bronchus. They are polymicrobial in nature including anaerobes and microaerophilic streptococci. Aspiration is a major risk factor (hence alcoholic patients are at higher risk).
  • Secondary lung abscess usually occurs in the presence of an underlying lung or systemic condition. The location of the abscess varies with the underlying condition. Generally, they occur due to a broad bacterial spectrum including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative rods.

Clinical features include fever, night sweats, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, and chest pain. 

Physical examination usually reveals poor dentition/gingival disease, digital clubbing, and absence of a gag reflex. Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds can be heard during auscultation.

Chest x-ray features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • Thick and irregular cavity wall and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate

Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities.

Clindamycin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or moxifloxacin can be administered for primary lung abscesses. Antibiotics for secondary lung abscesses are prescribed according to the pathogen identified. The treatment is usually prolonged until the resolution of the abscess is achieved. Treatment duration may range from 3–4 weeks to as long as 14 weeks.

The two radiograph images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: The fusion of the marked area in the image is completed by ____.
questions.solution:
The lower two parts of the sternal body are fused by the age of 14 years. The four middle pieces of the sternum fuse with one another from below upwards between 14 and 25 years.

Sternum development and ossification:

  • It develops by the fusion of two sternal plates formed on either side of the midline.
  • Ossification centers for the manubrium, the 1st and 2nd sternebrae, appear in 5th fetal month. The 3rd and 4th appear in the 5th and 6th months. 
  • These fuse below upwards during puberty and fusion is complete by 25 years.

Note:

  • The center for the xiphoid appears during the third year and fuses with the body by 40 years.
  • The manubrium unites with the body at 60 years.

questions.text: In judicial hanging, the knot is placed ________.

choices.text: At the angle of right jaw
At the back of the neck
As per the choice of the hangman

questions.solution:
In judicial hanging, the knot is placed at the angle of the right jaw.

Judicial hanging

  • Face of the person is covered with a dark mask, he is made to stand on a platform over trapdoors, which open downwards when a blot is drawn.
  • Rope is looped around the neck and the person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age, and build of the person.
  • Sudden stop causes fracture dislocation usually at the C2-C3 or C3-C4 vertebra level and rupture of the brainstem between pons and medulla. (hangman fracture).
  • Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for a considerable time.
  • Asphyxia signs are not seen in properly performed judicial hangings.

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears may be found

ecchymoses
