questions.text: The dose-response curve for the effects of three drugs on the same tissue is shown in the image below. Which of the following represents drug A and drug C, respectively, at μ receptor?
questions.solution:
In the given image, drugs A and drug C are agonists and partial agonists, which can be a combination of fentanyl and buprenorphine, respectively.

Drugs that are only partially as effective as agonists are partial agonists. Drug C does not produce a full response at any concentration, making it a partial agonist. In the given graph, fentanyl is an agonist at the μ receptor producing a response of drug A and buprenorphine is a partial agonist at μ receptor producing sub-maximal response.

Drugs that bind to physiological receptors and mimic the regulatory effects of endogenous signaling compounds are agonists. When two drugs produce equivalent responses, the drug whose dose-response curve lies to the left is said to be the more potent since it requires a lower dose to produce the same effect. Drug A and drug B produce the same action and level of response in the tissue. The curve of drug A on the left indicates that it produces the same response at a lower concentration, making it more potent than drug B. Fentanyl and methadone(option A), morphine and hydromorphone(option B), methadone and morphine(option D) are examples of the same.

questions.text: Paroxysmal AV block is a type of which of the following types of atrioventricular blocks, as represented by their ECG patterns?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal AV block is a series of non conducted P waves associated with Mobitz type II Second-degree AV block, which is depicted by the ECG pattern shown in image 1.

Paroxysmal AV block occurs in the presence of significant conductive system disease and warrants the use of a pacemaker.

Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block (Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Other options: 

Image B: It shows an ECG recording with prolonged PR interval (> 0.2s) and equal RR intervals. This is indicative of First Degree Heart Block.

Image C: It shows an ECG recording with the following findings:

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

This is seen in Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

Image D: It shows an ECG recording with progressive PR elongartion leading to an eventual drop of the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes and is indicative of Second-degree heart block (Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach phenomenon)

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A man met with a road traffic accident, which resulted in paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will you advise regarding radiography?

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support.
Order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.

questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used for radiography after neck stabilization.

Management in a trauma patient with a suspected cervical fracture involves the following steps:

  1. Spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board is the immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases.
  2. It is followed by a gross assessment of spinal cord function by eliciting extremity movement. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicative of an associated fracture.
  3. Imaging is done by X-ray or CT. Portable X-ray machines are preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but not the cervicothoracic junction. Cervical CT has been made the modality of choice in most emergency departments owing to the high quality of images that can be obtained.

questions.text: A young male patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is ideal for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a transverse fracture of the patella, and the ideal management for this is tension-band wiring.

The patient presents with pain and swelling over the affected knee. Patellar tenderness and bruise over the front of the joint can be present. Crepitus may be felt in comminuted fractures. The patient cannot lift his leg in full extension(extension lag) due to the disruption of the extensor apparatus. Hemarthrosis can be associated.

Patellar fractures can be transverse, longitudinal, polar, or comminuted.

The radiological examination includes AP and lateral views. A skyline view of the patella is required in some cases of undisplaced fractures.

Management of patellar fractures: 

Undisplaced fractures: It is treated with a plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension. This is called a cylinder cast (option A) and is usually left in place for a period of at least 3 weeks.

A transverse fracture is treated by a surgical procedure consisting of the reduction of the fragments known as tension-band wiring and K- wire fixation. This is followed by the repair of the extensor retinacula and physiotherapy.

Comminuted fractures are treated by open reduction and fixation. Patellectomy (option C) is the preferred option in this case as restoration of a smooth articular surface is difficult in this condition. Patella-saving operations are recently more performed with advancements in fixation techniques.

Longitudinal fractures usually have intact extensor apparatus. They can be treated with a cylinder cast or extension brace initially, followed by a range of motion.

Complications are knee stiffness, extensor weakness, and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern of ABO blood grouping?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern of the ABO blood grouping system is codominance.

Gene expression and mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive; in some cases, both of the alleles of a gene pair contribute to the phenotype—a condition called codominance. Examples include histocompatibility and ABO blood group antigens.

Classification of genetic disorders

Mendelian disorders (Classic inheritance)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Autosomal recessive
  • X-linked dominant
  • X-linked recessive

Non-mendelian disorders ( Non-classic inheritance)

  • Trinucleotide repeat mutations
    • Fragile X syndrome
    • Friedreich ataxia
    • Huntington’s disease
  • Mutations in mitochondrial genes: MELAS, MERRF
  • Genomic imprinting
    • Angelman syndrome
    • Prader–Willi syndrome
    • Silver–Russell syndrome
  • Gonadal mosaicism

Chromosomal disorders:

  • Microdeletions: Cri du chat syndrome
  • Down’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

Autosomal dominant
Autosomal recessive

(alpha1- antitrypsin deficiency)

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is done using the instrument shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image depicted is that of a Karman's cannula. It is used in suction and evacuation (S&E).

Suction and Evacuation (S&E) is the procedure of choice for medical termination of pregnancy in 7-12 weeks. The products of conception are sucked out of the uterus with a Karman's cannula attached to a suction apparatus working at 600 mmHg. 

 Endpoint of the procedure is marked by the following: 

  1. No more material is sucked out
  2. Appearance of air bubbles
  3. Gripping of the cannula by the contracting smaller size uterus
  4. Appearance of grating sound

Indications of suction and evacuation:  

  • 1st-trimester medical termination of pregnancy 
  • Inevitable abortion 
  • Recent incomplete abortion 
  • Hydatidiform mole

The image below shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A male baby born at term from uncomplicated delivery develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. The chest x-ray shows a diffuse ground-glass appearance of lung fields. Surfactant replacement and mechanical ventilation fail to improve hypoxemia. There is a history of death of a term male sibling at 1 month of age due to respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of respiratory distress and no response to surfactant therapy in a newborn and a family history of sibling death point toward a diagnosis of neonatal pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).

It is a disorder characterized by intra-alveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant due to abnormal surfactant production or impaired clearance by alveolar macrophages. Inherited PAP occurs due to the dysfunction of various surfactant proteins.

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is classified into primary and secondary PAP. Primary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is caused due to disruption of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signaling. Secondary PAP is caused due to several different diseases that reduce alveolar macrophage number or function.

In the neonatal period, the disease may manifest as a severe respiratory failure whereas in older children it has an insidious onset of chronic interstitial lung disease. Infants present with symptoms of dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis.

Chest x-ray shows diffuse alveolointerstitial infiltrates presenting as ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy is the gold standard investigation to diagnose PAP. Latex agglutination tests for the presence of anti–GM-CSF antibodies in BAL fluid or blood can also be done. They are highly sensitive and specific for the autoimmune forms of alveolar proteinosis.

The disease is progressive and is refractory to surfactant replacement therapy. Neonates with severe respiratory failure require mechanical ventilation and can also be treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. Neonatal intensive care interventions and lung transplantation have been successful in a few cases. A total lung lavage is a therapeutic option for patients with childhood PAP. Subcutaneous or inhaled administration of recombinant GM-CSF may improve pulmonary function in some adults with later-onset PAP. 

Other options:

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) presents immediately after birth, with features of respiratory distress due to aspiration of meconium in utero, resulting in airway obstruction. Most cases improve well with supportive care and mechanical ventilation. 

Option C: Hyaline membrane disease occurs in premature infants due to surfactant deficiency. Distress ensues within a few minutes of birth. If untreated, it may result in respiratory failure. Surfactant replacement therapy and mechanical ventilation will greatly improve the condition.

Option D: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is self-limiting tachypnea occurring in full-term infants due to reduced clearance of fetal lung fluid. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for the treatment of glaucoma. He came to the ophthalmological outpatient department with a change in the appearance of his eyes, as shown in the given image. Identify the mechanism of action of the drug he was taking.
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of iris pigmentation, which is seen as a side-effect of topical prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost. The mechanism of action of these drugs is increased uveoscleral outflow.

Other side effects of topical prostaglandins:

  • Brown pigmentation of iris and eyelash
  • Dry eyes
  • Macular edema
  • Blurred vision
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes(Hypertrichosis)

The main classes of drugs used in glaucoma and their respective mechanism of action are illustrated below:

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects
Beta-blockers

Corneal hypoesthesia

Systemic side effects
Sympathomimetics

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)
Prostaglandin analogs

Eyelash hypertrichosis

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

Peri-orbital fat depletion

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Systemic side effects

Corneal edema

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with itchy erythematous punctate papules with weals after eating spicy food, exercising, and after a hot bath.  What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the development of itchy erythematous papular wheals that appear after exercise, eating spicy food, and a hot bath is suggestive of cholinergic urticaria. 

Cholinergic urticaria is an inducible urticaria that is common in adolescents. It occurs to due stimulation of the cholinergic post-ganglionic sympathetic nerve supply to eccrine sweat glands. It may be triggered by a rise in core body temperature, spicy food, or emotion and lasts for a few minutes to 1-2 hours. Cholinergic angioedema can occur along with urticaria.

Diagnosis is confirmed by provocation tests wherein typical itchy weals on an erythematous background appear after warming such as after a hot bath at 42°C for 15 min, to raise the core temperature by 0.7 to 1°C – or by exercising in a hot environment. Systemic symptoms such as asthma, flushing, and fainting can also occur during these episodes.

Persistent cholinergic urticaria is characterized by multiple small erythematous macules distributed symmetrically on the trunk and limbs which increase in number after exercise.

Laboratory tests reveal increased histamine levels and decreased protease inhibitor levels of antichymotrypsin in these patients.

Other options:

Option A: In solar urticaria, weals develop within minutes of exposure to UV radiation. Usually, they fade within hours.

Option B: In aquagenic urticaria, weals surrounded by a wide flare similar to cholinergic urticaria develop after exposure to cold water. 

Option D: Cooling of the core body temperature induces a generalized wealing in systemic cold urticaria. In cold‐induced cholinergic urticaria, additional exercise is necessary for the cold room to induce weals.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the emergency department following several episodes of blood-stained vomitus. The patient reported that the symptoms started after attempts of forceful retching after a binge-eating episode. Her endoscopy finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Mallory-Weiss tears. The given clinical scenario describes bulimia, which is a disorder in which the patient first indulges in binge eating and then vomits out the food. Forceful vomiting in bulimia may lead to Mallory-Weiss tears.

Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal tears near the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory-Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail

Option A: Barrett's esophagus presents clinically with features similar to GERD. The patients complain of heartburn, dysphagia, and regurgitation of sour-tasting gastric contents, most often post-prandially.

Option B: Esophageal varices are tortuous dilated veins within the mucosa and submucosa of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach. Variceal hemorrhage is an emergency that can be treated medically by inducing splanchnic vasoconstriction or endoscopically by sclerotherapy, balloon tamponade, or variceal ligation.

Option C: Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural tearing and rupture of the distal esophagus. This catastrophic event produces severe mediastinitis and generally requires surgical intervention. The patients initially present with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the casualty after being involved in a motorcycle accident. CT scan of the head is shown. His GCS score is 6. What is the definitive treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Extradural Hematoma (EDH) as the CT scan shows a hyperdense, biconvex lesion on the right side. As the patient is unstable (a large bleed with a GCS score of 6), surgical evacuation by craniotomy is the definitive treatment indicated.

A craniotomy is indicated for most patients with EDH, but, patients who meet all of the following criteria may be managed conservatively:

  • Clot volume < 30 cc
  • Maximum thickness < 1.5 cm
  • Glasgow coma score > 8

Extra Dural Hematoma

Other options:

Nimodipine is used to prevent vasospasm in patients with Sub-Arachnoid Hemorrhage. Hyperventilation is also part of the triple H therapy used for subarachnoid hemorrhage. Intravenous mannitol, though can serve to lower the intracranial pressure in conditions with a raised ICP, it is not a definitive treatment option.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: An HIV-positive male patient comes to the clinic with a complaint of watery diarrhea. He is not on antiretroviral therapy.  A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. A wet mount of the freshly passed stool of the patient reveals the following picture. What is true about these helminths?

choices.text: Rhabditiform larva is infective for humans
It is usually transmitted through contaminated food and water
Females of these species are ovoviviparous
Drug of choice for treatment is triclabendazole

questions.solution:
The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with watery diarrhea and stool revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. Females of these species are ovoviviparous is the correct statement.

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous, meaning they release live microfilariae into the surrounding host tissues. Adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall causing internal reinfection or perianal skin causing autoinfection. Filariform larvae passed in stools are present in soil and infect others through penetration of the skin of feet. 

The life cycle of Strongyloides is shown below:

It causes cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli, leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms. 

Intestinal manifestations may resemble those of peptic ulcer or of malabsorption syndrome. Mucus diarrhea is often present. Other manifestations are protein-losing enteropathy and paralytic ileus.

Larva currens (racing larvae) is a skin lesion that starts perianally and occurs due to autoinfection. It causes rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks due to the migration of filariform larvae in the skin called, as shown in the image below.

Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the freshly passed stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis. Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels are seen. 

Ivermectin is the preferred agent over albendazole in the management of strongyloidiasis.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

questions.text: The findings of stool examination in a patient are shown below. What is the likely route of infection with this parasite?

choices.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with the egg of larva
Inhalation of dust particles containing eggs

questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). The likely route of infection with this parasite is the ingestion of food contaminated with the egg of the larva. 

Characteristic features of whipworm eggs:

  • Eggs are bile-stained; hence, they are brown in color.
  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.

The mode of transmission in humans is when the mature embryonated eggs containing the infective larvae are swallowed in contaminated food or water. The eggs hatch in the small intestine. The larva, which emerges through the pole of the egg, passes down into the cecum.

Humans are the only natural hosts for T. trichiura. Infection with T. trichiura cause anemia, abdominal pain, anorexia, and bloody or mucoid diarrhea. Rectal prolapse can result from massive infections in children who often suffer from malnourishment and other diarrheal illnesses.

Other options:

Option B: The mode of infection for Taenia saginata is the consumption of undercooked beef containing Cysticercus bovis.

Option C: The mode of transmission for Filariae is through the bite of blood-sucking insects.

Option D: Ascaris and Enterobius infection is transmitted through inhalation of dust particles containing eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of skin lesions on the forehead as shown in the image. Which of the following is a causative agent of this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows skin lesions characteristically appearing as shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by molluscum contagiosum virus, which is classified within the poxvirus family.

The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. 

It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen i.e., new lesions develop along a line of trauma.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required, and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously. Stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and imiquimod. Cryotherapy when done needs to be repeated at 3-4 week intervals. Extensive lesions are treated with an antiviral agent like cidofovir.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room with fever and hypotension. She has rigors, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Her BP is 70/50 mmHg; SpO2, 89%; respiratory rate, 26/min; pulse, 140 bpm; and temperature, 39.5°C. She opens her eyes when you ask her to do so, produces only sounds, and withdraws her leg when you stroke it with the knee hammer. What is the qSOFA score of this patient?
questions.solution:
qSOFA score for this patient would be 3. Only 3 parameters are considered for its calculation, and the respective scores are as follows:

  • BP: 70/50 mmHg → Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg) → Score 1
  • Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min → High (≥22 breaths/min) → Score 1
  • Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score: 9/15 → Altered mentation (GCS score, <15) → Score 1
    • Opens her eyes on command -E3
    • Produces only sounds-V2
    • Withdraws leg when stroked with the knee hammer-M4

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • high respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min),
  • altered mentation (GCS score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis. This is a simplified derivative of SOFA score. The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score, which includes assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP and need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 and need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow Coma Scale score 
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin level
  • Renal function - Creatinine level

A SOFA score of ≥2 defines organ dysfunction. Another score that has been used is the National Early Warning Score (NEWS). It ranges from 0 to 20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature, systolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and level of consciousness. ≥5 out of 20 is considered a positive score. 

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

  • The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.
  • The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System (LODS) score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

GCS Score

  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, weight loss, and fever. A peripheral blood smear was done and showed the following findings. Which among the following will indicate a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the bone marrow histology suggest a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Presence of a t(12;21) indicates a good prognosis.

ALL patients present with symptoms of impaired marrow function like anemia, infections secondary to neutropenia, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Other symptoms include bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, testicular enlargement, headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies.

Prognostic factors are identified in every patient to stratify them into risk groups that help in deciding the treatment. Minimal residual disease (MRD) is the most important prognostic factor during therapy. MRD refers to the detection of residual leukemic cells that are not recognizable by light microscopy after the therapy. MRD is a reflection of the response to treatment. 

Treatment of ALL

  • Induction: L-Asparaginase, vincristine, prednisolone, and anthracycline
  • CNS prophylaxis with intrathecal methotrexate
  • Consolidation: Methotrexate, cytarabine 
  • Maintenance: 6-Mercaptopurine, methotrexate plus intrathecal therapy

 

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

Good prognostic markers  Bad prognostic markers 
Age between 2 and 10 years 

Age younger than 2 years 

Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
Low white cell count  Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000,
Female  Male 
Hyperdiploidy  Hypodiploidy  
Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, 10 & 17  Pseudodiploidy or t (9;22)  or t (8;14) or t (4;11)

Early precursor B cell phenotype  T cell phenotype

questions.text: An adult presents with massive proteinuria, edema, and hematuria. The biopsy image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous nephropathy is a chronic immune complex–mediated disease characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

It will present as nephrotic syndrome with massive proteinuria, generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria. Most of the cases are primary. Some of the secondary causes include

  • Drugs (penicillamine, captopril, NSAIDs, gold),
  • Malignant tumors- Lung, colon, and melanoma
  • SLE
  • Infections -Chronic Hep B, Hep C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders. 

In RPGN Type I and Goodpasture syndrome, a characteristic linear pattern is observed on immunofluorescence which is a classic anti-GBM disease. Minimal Change disease has negative immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of hearing loss. On further evaluation, he has been diagnosed with a profound hearing impairment. Which of the following is the corresponding audiometric ISO value and grading according to the WHO classification of hearing impairment?
questions.solution:
Hearing impairment of more than 81 dB, Grade IV in the better ear in adults is regarded as profound hearing impairment with deafness according to the WHO grading of hearing impairment.

WHO grading of hearing impairment:

Grade of impairment Corresponding Audiometric ISO value Performance Recommendations
0: No impairment 25 dB or better No or very slight hearing problems. Can hear whispers None
1: Slight impairment  26–40 dB Able to hear and repeat words spoken in a normal voice at 1 m Counselling. Hearing aids may be needed.
2: Moderate impairment 41–55 dB Able to hear and repeat words using a raised voice at 1 m Hearing aids are usually recommended,
3: Severe impairment  56–70 dB Able to hear some words when shouted into a better ear Hearing aids are needed. If hearing aids are not available, lip-reading should be taught.

4: Profound impairment including deafness

(a)  Profound hearing impairment 

(b) Near-total deafness

(c) Total deafness

 

 

71-90 dB

91 dB and above in better ear 

No hearing

 Unable to hear and understand even a shouted voice Hearing aids may help in understanding words. Additional rehabilitation is needed. Lip-reading and sometimes signing are essential.

 

Grade V of hearing impairment does not exist.

questions.text:
Match the following -

A - Calcium oxalate
B - Struvite
C - Cystine
D - Uric acid
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are -

1 - C. Cystine

2 - B. Struvite

3 - A. Calcium oxalate

4 - D. Uric acid

Cystine -Patients with cystinuria (an autosomal recessive disorder) are at risk for developing cystine stones.

Struvite stones -  Urease-producing organisms such as Proteus or Klebsiella causing chronic upper urinary tract infection are at higher risk for struvite stones. the are magnesium-ammonium phosphate stones. 

Calcium stones - Seen in conditions causing high urine calcium such as primary hyperparathyroidism and chronic acidemia from distal renal tubular acidosis. Also seen in the condition of high urine oxalate which is seen during a low-calcium diet and in malabsorption syndromes(small bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease), including a jejunoileal bypass for obesity (bariatric surgery), surgical bowel resection or diversion, or cystic fibrosis).

Uric Acid stones - Gout and Diabetes Mellitus are associated with uric acid stones.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: While carrying out a postmortem analysis of a victim, which of the following features will be consistent with an antemortem burn?

choices.text: Dry, hard and yellow blister base
Absent line of redness around wound

questions.solution:
The presence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood is highly suggestive of death due to antemortem burns. A blood hemoglobin saturation of >10% with carbon monoxide is indicative of antemortem smoke inhalation.

This is in contrast to postmortem burns, wherein carboxyhemoglobin levels are not elevated as it is not possible for the gas to diffuse through the skin or be otherwise absorbed by a dead body.  

Other options:

Option A: Dry, hard, and yellow blister base is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the inflamed, red base of blisters seen in antemortem burns.

Option B: Absent line of redness around burn wounds is seen in postmortem burns. This vital reaction, termed red flare, is present in antemortem burns.

Option C: Reduced enzymatic activity around the wound is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the significant increase in enzyme activity (cathepsin, aminopeptidase, alkaline phosphatase) as seen in an antemortem burn.

Related Pearl: Differences between antemortem and postmortem burns

 

Characteristics Antemortem burns Postmortem burns

Vital sign Present Absent
Vesication / Blister Present and true, contains serous fluid

Present but are false, contains PM gases +/- thin clear fluid
Reparative process Present Absent
Internal organs Congested

Usually burnt+emits peculiar odor
Blood colour Cherry red due to CO Normal
Curling’s ulcer Present Absent
Inflamed Payer’s patches Present Absent

Carbon/ soot particles in the trachea, bronchus

 Present  Absent

Peripheral zone of burn 

 Shows an increase in enzyme reaction Does not show an increase in enzyme reaction

questions.text: What is this postmortem ocular finding shown in the image below known as? How will you be able to see this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows the fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels known as the Kevorkian sign. It occurs due to the loss of blood pressure and can be seen only through an ophthalmoscope. This sign lasts for about 1 hour.

Tache noir is a black-colored deposition of cell debris, and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death, which can be seen through the naked eye. 

Initially, yellow-colored triangles appear on either side of the cornea with the apex pointing towards the canthus. The color then progressively changes to brown and black, followed by wrinkling of the surface.

Image of Tache noir is seen below:

 
Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:
  • Loss of corneal reflex
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Dilatation of pupil due to relaxation of muscles of the iris
  • Increased potassium concentration in vitreous up to 100 hours following death.

questions.text: A volunteer's medication history was taken before the start of an experiment. On testing, the bleeding time was found to be increased. All the following can be causative agents, except ______.
questions.solution:
Among the listed drugs, vitamin K supplements do not prolong bleeding time.

Vitamin K acts as a cofactor at a late stage in the synthesis of coagulation proteins by the liver—prothrombin, factors VII, IX, and X. It helps in γ carboxylation of glutamate residues conferring on them the capacity to bind Ca2+ and to get bound to phospholipid surfaces. This property is essential for participation in the coagulation cascade.

Its deficiency causes bleeding tendency due to reduced prothrombin and other clotting factors. Taking vitamin K supplements hardly produces any adverse effect, and it does not prolong bleeding time.

Inamrinone is a phosphodiesterase 3 (PDE3) inhibitor used in heart failure. Linezolid binds to 50S ribosome and interferes with the formation of the ternary N­ formylmethionine­ tRNA-­70S initiation complex and inhibits protein synthesis in bacteria. Both these drugs cause thrombocytopenia which results in increased bleeding time.

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits thromboxaneA2 synthesis by platelets. Thus, it interferes with platelet aggregation and prolongs bleeding time.

questions.text: The buccinator muscle is pierced by all, except _______.
questions.solution:
The buccinator muscle is not pierced by the buccal branch of facial nerve. It runs across the muscle and innervates it without piercing it.

Buccinator Muscle:

  • Origin – Mandible, Alveolar processes of maxilla and mandible, Pterygomandibular raphe
  • Insertion – Angle of mouth, Orbicularis oris
  • Structures piercing the buccinator:
    • Parotid duct (Stenson’s duct)
    • Molar mucous glands of buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Buccal branch of mandibular nerve
  • Action:
    • Aids mastication
    • Tenses cheeks in blowing and whistling
    • Aids closure of the mouth

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with an altered sensorium. A non-contrast CT revealed hydrocephalus, requiring urgent surgical intervention. The patient had nobody accompanying her or any identity proof. Under which of these sections of the BNS (IPC) can the neurosurgeon perform the procedure without obtaining informed consent from the guardian?

IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 30 (92 IPC) deals with an act that is done in good faith without consent.

The following situations would apply:

  • Emergency (No need to take consent during emergencies)
  • The person is incapable of giving consent
  • The person has no guardian to give consent

Other options:

Option A- BNS Sec 28 (90 IPC) deals with consent known to be given under fear or misconception and consent of the insane person.

Option C- BNS Sec 33 (95 IPC) deals with the act causing slight harm.

Option D- BNS Sec 26 (88 IPC) deals with acts done by consent in good faith for a person's benefit, not intended to cause death. 

Related Pearl: Consent

BNS Section

Provisions under the Act

Previous IPC section

25

Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent is not an offense.

87

26

An act done by consent in good faith for a person’s benefit is not an offense.

88

27

An act done in good faith for the benefit of a child under 12 years of age or an insane person, with the consent of a parent or guardian is not an offense.

89

28

Consent is invalid if

  • Given under fear or misconception.
  • Given by an insane person

90

29

The exceptions in sections 25, 26, and 27 do not extend to acts that are offenses independently of any harm which they may cause, or be intended to cause or be known to be likely to cause, to the person giving the consent, or on whose behalf the consent is given.

 

30

The act is done in good faith without consent in the following situations:

  • Emergency (No need to take consent during emergencies)
  • The person is incapable of giving consent
  • The person has no guardian to give consent

92

33

Act causing slight harm is not an offense

95

 

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharata Nyaya Samhita Document 2023

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with hepatitis C infection now presents to the hospital with reddish-colored urine. Urine analysis was performed, and it shows proteinuria and the presence of red blood cells and leucocytes in the urine. A renal biopsy was performed, and the obtained sample was stained with periodic acid-Schiff (image A) and methenamine silver (image B). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is diagnosed with hepatitis C, presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and pyuria and histological examination shows the thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, giving rise to the tram-track appearance. The most likely diagnosis in this case is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is immune-mediated glomerulonephritis characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with mesangio-proliferative changes.

Types:

Type I MPGN is commonly associated with persistent hepatitis C infections, autoimmune diseases like SLE or cryoglobulinemia, or neoplastic diseases of the lung, breast, and ovary. 

Type II and type III are mediated by the complement pathways.

Histopathology:

On light microscopy, type I MPGN will show the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. At some points, the GBM splits showing the tram track appearance. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits.

Type II MPGN can also have GBM thickening and splitting. The glomerular tuft has a lobular appearance. On electron microscopy, it shows dense deposits. Subendothelial deposits are generally absent.

Type III MPGN is rare and shows focal mesangial proliferation. The image below shows the thickening and splitting of GBM.

Other options

Option A- Crescentic glomerulonephritis is seen in patients developing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In this, the serum creatinine levels increase very rapidly. Microscopy will show the presence of crescents within the glomeruli.

Option C - Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is usually a primary disease, but rarely can be associated with diseases like Hodgkin’s lymphoma, allergies, or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents. Light microscopy appears normal. Electron microscopy may show the effacement of foot processes.

Option D - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis manifests as proteinuria. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It can be a primary disease or occur as a result of HIV, hepatitis B, hypertension, Alport syndrome, etc. The biopsy will show the focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient comes with fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea and is diagnosed with HIV. He has been using oral ketoconazole for tinea infection. Which of the following drugs should not be concomitantly used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is taking ketoconazole should not receive saquinavir—a protease inhibitor.

The antifungal agent ketoconazole is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and other CYPs, and coadministration of ketoconazole with the anti-HIV viral protease inhibitors reduces the clearance of the protease inhibitor and increases its plasma concentration and the risk of toxicity.

  • Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI) like abacavir and zidovudine do not interact much with CYP enzymes. (Option A and B)
  • The only nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor tenofovir does not interact much with CYP enzymes. (Option D)
  • Nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) like efavirenz and nevirapine are moderately potent inducers of hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes, including CYP3A4.
  • Protease inhibitors inhibit CYP3A4 at clinically achieved concentrations, with ritonavir by far the most potent.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive difficulty in breathing for the past 5 days. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.2°C and blood pressure of 155/96 mmHg. The percussion note over both lung bases is stony dull and the chest x-ray shows a bilateral pleural effusion. Echocardiography revealed small vegetation on both sides of the mitral valve. Her ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results are positive. Which of the following cardiac illnesses is most likely to be present in her?
questions.solution:
The anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results are positive, which indicate the underlying diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a complication of SLE, characterized by small, sterile vegetations that may occur anywhere over valves, chordae, and endocardium.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a type of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). It is associated with autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The deposition of immune complexes leads to the formation of small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations on heart valves. 

Vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Histologically, there is intense valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance.

Patients may present with symptoms of stroke or TIA's due to emboli from the vegetation.

Vegetations are often associated with severe valvulitis, characterized by fibrinoid necrosis of the valve, and reflect the activation of complement and recruitment of Fc-receptor-bearing cells.

Other options:

Option A: Calcific aortic stenosis may be seen in older individuals as a consequence of age-associated wear and tear, involving tricuspid or bicuspid valves.

Option B: Although pericarditis is common in SLE, it is serous, not hemorrhagic.

Option D: Rheumatic heart disease is an immunologic disease and serologic tests would be positive for antistreptolysin O (ASO), not ANA.
